urn:contentItem:55W7-5501-F0NT-H4KH-00000-00Another dire UN report, but still no action2012-06-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisAnother dire UN report, but still no actionDavid BowmanABSTRACT

The prognosis of the latest UN report on the environment is alarming. But with the public immune to predictions of long-term disaster, the political will for appropriate action appears some way off.

FULL TEXT

The Conversation

The fifth edition of the Global Environmental Outlook (GEO-5) - a global environmental report card by the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) - reads like the results for a sedentary, middle-aged, overweight, binge drinking, heavy smoker.

Low points of the report include:

-- Evidence of climate change, including a 230 per cent increase in flood disasters and 38 per cent in drought disasters between the 1980s and 2000;

-- Threat of extinction of one-fifth of all vertebrates; and

-- Collapse of some marine ecosystems due to pollution and overfishing, and the creation of 169 "coastal dead zones."

Collectively, the prognosis of the GEO-5 report is dire, warning: "if humanity does not urgently change its ways, several critical thresholds may be exceeded, beyond which abrupt and generally irreversible changes to the life-support functions of the planet could occur."

These changes have profound implications for humanity. It is now certain that the future of the biosphere will be very different to what we have been acculturated to believe is 'normal' or 'natural'. We are yet to discover what it will be like, psycho-socially, to exist in an overpopulated and ecologically stressed world, where everyone knows the environment quality was substantially better for the previous generation.

Is it consistent with a civilisation on the brink of global environmental transformation that there should be a tiny investment in monitoring planetary health relative to, say, making blockbuster movies? The lack of data is a real problem for any accurate predictions of the future, particularly because we are unable to understand how the various components of the Earth system will interact.

It is true that satellite imagery now provides excellent global, and in some cases daily, coverage of changes to the atmosphere, and land and sea surface. But there are critical aspects of the Earth system that remain poorly monitored, including assessments of trends (such as functioning of marine and terrestrial ecosystems) and the effects of pollution and invasive organisms.

The GEO-5 report acknowledged that the lack of good data makes it difficult to get an accurate picture of the state of the global environment. Problematically, the functioning of the earth system hinges on the interaction of numerous ecological components. Scientists have only a rudimentary understanding of these interrelationships. In some cases trends may amplify each other; coral reefs, for example, are dying due to synergistic effects of global warming, overfishing and pollution.

The GEO-5 report provides some good news. Successes have included international treaties and agreements, phasing out ozone depleting chemicals and near-complete removal of lead in fuel. This shows humans will respond to immediate and clearly defined threats. There has been a steady expansion of declared national parks (even if funding for their management is insufficient) and increased efforts to slow the rate of deforestation.

Still, we are struggling to come to grips with more diffuse and intractable problems, such as climate change, water management, loss of biodiversity, human population growth and inequitable resource consumption. In these cases there is no simple remedy. Achieving global action has proven to be far more difficult. It needs poly-government policy development and enforcement, technological innovation and adoption. And while we're working on these, the sheer complexity means we risk perverse outcomes, such as destroying Indonesia's forests for 'sustainable' biofuels.

The report says an "ambitious set of sustainability targets by the middle of the century is possible if current policies and strategies are changed and strengthened." The question of who guards the global environmental guardians required to enforce these policies remains unresolved. But more fundamentally, achieving global environmental stewardship demands an iron political will at a global scale. And this, in turn, demands global constituency building. Until the global population cares enough, the political will to make changes won't be there.

Effectively communicating to the global community the bad news about the trajectory of the Earth system presents a substantial problem. Doctors know that shouting at a patient with an unhealthy lifestyle does not change their behaviour.

Often the driver for urgently lifestyle change comes from a major health scare. Despite describing a trajectory of unprecedented global environmental changes, the GEO-5 report does not carry enough emotional freight to galvanise global action. And it is obvious that the recent litany of environmental disasters - Deepwater Horizon oil spill, Fukushima nuclear disaster, Black Saturday bushfires, Central America floods, Frenchheat waves, Moscow forest fire smoke disaster and so on - have not prompted significant changes in human behaviour towards the Earth system. Part of the problem is that these disasters can be considered in isolation, framed against 'natural' background risk, and thereby rationalised, blunting the clear signal that human civilisation is exposed to tremendous risk from both natural and anthropogenic extreme events.

The current state of the global environment is like a phony war. Nothing particularly bad has happened yet, despite protestation from environmental activists that something grave will happen soon. Nonetheless, the steady stream of data and reports, such as GEO-5, are all signalling that the future global environment will be seriously challenging - real war (literally and metaphorically) will eventually break out.

In the meantime, environmental scientists are caught in a bind - the public is numb to shock-and-awe predictions of global catastrophe. And in any case, scientific prognoses are constrained by the overwhelming complexity of the Earth system, which is poorly understood or monitored. There remains little serious science investment compared to the funding for the discovery of fundamental physical phenomena at the quantum or astronomical scales.

Beyond the certainty of dramatic global environmental changes, the only certainty is uncertainty. I suspect that most people have accepted that the environment will be dramatically transformed in their, and certainly their kids, lifetimes. But they are either in serious denial or hoping for the best. It seems collectively humans only demand drastic political change when confronted by overwhelmingly compelling and immediate threats. And as the Arab Spring has taught us, revolutionary moments are not always ordered or peaceful. It is a brave new world indeed.

This article was originally publishedby The Conversation. Reproduced with permission.

urn:contentItem:44K9-G620-0197-D4KH-00000-00<published>2000-02-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:20Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 4</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BLACK FRIDAY;<br/>Hotter, and then a brief sigh of relief</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By BEN HOOPER and KATE UREN</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ADELAIDE'S heatwave is set to continue well into next week.</p><p nitf:lede="true">After a maximum of 42 degrees today, the Bureau of Meteorology has forecast temperatures in the 30s throughout the weekend and for most of next week.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Adelaide recorded a maximum temperature of 39.8 at 2pm yesterday, before a sea breeze blew in and the temperature started slowly dropping. By 6pm the temperature was down to a more comfortable 31.</p><p>Marree and Oodnadatta recorded the State's highest temperature of 45 while Cape Willoughby on Kangaroo Island was the coolest, with a maximum of just 19.</p><p> Statewide fire bans are in place today with the extreme temperatures and forecast 35 km/h northerly winds increasing the fire danger.</p><p> As the temperature soared yesterday SA Ambulance crews reported seven heat-related cases, mostly involving the elderly, and are expecting no relief.</p><p> And school students across the State stayed indoors for lunch, sport was cancelled and many children were dismissed early.</p><p> Fifteen students at Prospect Rosary primary school were allowed to go home because of the heat. However, according to the Education Department, fewer than 10 per cent of schools would have dismissed students early.</p><p> Country Fire Service crews fought a forest fire in Second Valley, on the Fleurieu Peninsula, using two fire bombers to contain the blaze.</p><p> SA Water reported metropolitan consumption over the past three days almost matched the record of 1153 million litres on December 10, 1998.</p><p> Acting head of Water Services Peter Norman said while the systems were handling the demand well the "enormous" consumption was draining reserves which had led to more pumping from the River Murray.</p><p> Suburban shopping centres were hit hard by power cuts with thousands of outlets and customers left in the dark.</p><p> At the Findon shopping centre a power cut brought the centre to a virtual standstill for more than 30 minutes.</p><p> Australia Post, the National Australia Bank and the Findon library were all forced to close their doors during the power cut. Other shops, such as the greengrocer and newsagency, struggled to serve customers by torchlight.</p><p> But butcher Gary Davidson, whose scales and cash register are electronic, was forced to wait angrily in his empty shop for the power to be restored before he could serve customers.</p><p> "I'm losing money because I can't serve anyone," Mr Davidson said.</p><p> The Findon Fruit Market brought out old-fashioned scales to weigh produce and served customers by torchlight.</p><p> "We're back to the good old days," said greengrocer Sophie Stanef.</p><p> At Windsor Gardens, the blackout struck the Windsor Hotel at lunch time, leaving 150 hungry customers waiting for their meals and manager Helen Ward outraged.</p><p> "It was absolutely bloody ridiculous, just shocking," Ms Ward said.</p><p> "This is about the sixth time it's happened to me in the last few months. It usually happens about 3.30pm, but today it was the worst possible time for us.</p><p> "I know it's hot and everybody's using their airconditioners, but they should be able to cater for all of this."</p><p>City forecast</p><p>42  TODAY  Very hot</p><p>30  TOMORROW  Cloudy periods</p><p>33  SUNDAY Fine and mostly sunny</p><p>36  MONDAY  Fine and mostly sunny</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:44H4-3JF0-00RC-42T6-00000-00<published>2001-11-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:20Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Financial News news</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>PBR - Quarterly Report - Second Quarter April april</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">HOMEX - Sydney<br/>-------------------------<br/>Quarterly Report - Second Quarter April to September 2001MESSAGE FROM THE HONOURABLE GARY COLLINSMINISTER OF FINANCEI am pleased to present the second Quarterly Report for the 2001/02<br/>fiscal year. This report includes a new economic forecast for 2001<br/>and 2002. The combined effects of the recession in the United States<br/>and the preliminary countervailing duty on lumber exports to the US<br/>have had a significant effect on the British Columbia economy. As a<br/>result, we have lowered the British Columbia economic growth forecast<br/>to 0.9 per cent for 2001 and 0.6 per cent for 2002.This report includes financial results for the April-to-September<br/>period of the 2001/02 fiscal year. These show a deterioration in<br/>government revenues and in the financial position of certain major<br/>Crown corporations. This has been partly offset by expenditure<br/>control in most ministries. In total, the six-month surplus was $789<br/>million, or $76 million below budget. Without a one-time pension<br/>gain, the summary accounts would show a $617 million deficit.The Quarterly Report concludes with a revised financial forecast. The<br/>full-year deficit is now expected to be $2,036 million, or $55<br/>million higher than forecast in September. After removing a one-time<br/>$1,406 million pension gain, the forecast deficit stands at $3,442<br/>million. Changes in the forecast since September reflect a<br/>deterioration in natural resource revenues as energy prices have<br/>fallen faster than expected, and some setbacks in BC Rail and BC<br/>Hydro, partially offset by the effects of higher income tax returns<br/>for the 2000 taxation year. year.</p><p>I have been monitoring spending pressures<br/>in various ministries, and I am pleased to report that the spending<br/>situation has improved. We continue to face challenges in this area,<br/>in particular with health care pressures, and I acknowledge the<br/>significant effort of ministries in keeping spending under control.This is my second Quarterly Report as Minister of Finance. I have made<br/>some changes to the layout of the report in order to increase the<br/>focus on the most material changes and risks. I believe this enhances<br/>the transparency of our reporting in keeping with the intent of the<br/>Budget Transparency and Accountability Act.G Collins<br/>MINISTERMORE TO FOLLOW</p><p>HOMEX - Sydney<br/>-------------------------<br/>Quarterly Report - Second Quarter April to September 2001HIGHLIGHTS - ECONOMIC REVIEW AND OUTLOOK<br/>SECOND QUARTERLY REPORT 2001/02* The economic outlook has continued to deteriorate since the first<br/>Quarterly Report. The US economy fell into negative growth territory<br/>in the July-to-September quarter as a rapidly slowing economy was<br/>further impacted by the September 11 terrorist attacks.* In British Columbia, most economic indications were weak in the<br/>July-to-September quarter, reflecting the North American economic<br/>slowdown and the effect of the preliminary countervailing duty on<br/>lumber exports to the US.* Since the summer, private sector forecasters have progressively<br/>lowered their growth projections for the US, Canada and British<br/>Columbia.* Growth forecasts for British Columbia averaged 2.3 per cent for 2001<br/>and 3.2 per cent for 2002 in the summer. Private sector forecasts<br/>have subsequently eroded and now average 1.3 per cent for 2001 and 1.5<br/>per cent for 2002.* The British Columbia government has also lowered its forecast of<br/>British Columbia economic growth. Growth is now forecast to be 0.9<br/>per cent for 2001 and 0.6 per cent for 2002.* The revised forecast incorporates the unexpectedly rapid downturn in<br/>global economic activity, reduced consumer confidence in the US and<br/>Canada, and the preliminary US lumber countervailing and anti-dumping<br/>duty rulings on softwood lumber.* Due to the high degree of uncertainty encompassing the global<br/>economic outlook, the economic forecast is provided for two years<br/>only.* The government will be developing a five-year economic forecast for<br/>inclusion in the February 19 budget. It is expected that the length<br/>and extent of the global and in particular the North American economic<br/>slowdown will become clearer, allowing for greater certainty as to the<br/>medium term outlook.MORE TO FOLLOW</p><p>HOMEX - Sydney<br/>-------------------------<br/>Quarterly Report - Second Quarter April to September 2001HIGHLIGHTS - FISCAL YEAR-TO-DATE REPORTSECOND QUARTERLY REPORT 2001/02* The summary accounts showed a $789 million surplus for the first<br/>six months of 2001/02, $76 million below budget. After removing a one<br/>time pension gain of $1,406 million for joint trusteeship, the<br/>summary accounts would show a $617-million deficit.* The consolidated revenue fund shortfall was $89 million higher than<br/>planned. Revenues were $117 million below forecast primarily due to<br/>rapidly falling energy prices, while spending was $28 million below<br/>budget.(graph - Six-month Results (April-September)* Crown corporations and agency results were $113 million below plan,<br/>mainly due to unfavourable developments for BC Hydro and ICBC.* The estimated one-time pension accounting gain resulting from joint<br/>trusteeship increased by $126 million due to updated actuarial<br/>valuation information.* In total, provincial debt increased $1.645 million during the first<br/>six months of the year:- Taxpayer-supported debt increased $246 million.<br/>- Commercial Crown corporation debt increased $65 million.<br/>- Warehouse debt increased $1,334 million in anticipation of the<br/>province's cash requirements for the remainder of the year.MORE TO FOLLOW</p><p>HOMEX - Sydney<br/>-------------------------<br/>Quarterly Report - Second Quarter April to September 2001HIGHLIGHTS  REVISED FINANCIAL FORECAST<br/>SECOND QUARTERLY REPORT 2001/ 02* The summary accounts are projected to show a $2,036-million deficit<br/>for the 2001/02 fiscal year.* The forecast deficit is $55 million higher than the forecast in the<br/>first Quarterly Report and $536 million higher than the July 30<br/>Update.* After removing a one-time pension gain of $1,406 million for joint<br/>trusteeship, the forecast deficit is $3,442 million.* The projected consolidated revenue fund (CRF) shortfall increased<br/>$31 million since the first Quarterly Report. It is now $196 million<br/>higher than the July 30 Update, primarily due to lower natural<br/>resource revenue.* The spending plan remains on track. Most ministries are forecast to<br/>be on or below budget. However, risks exist in a number of areas,<br/>with the most significant being in Health Services. Health<br/>authorities are managing pressures in the range of $150 to $200<br/>million.* Crown corporations and agency forecasts have deteriorated $150<br/>million from the first Quarterly Report, and are now $341 million<br/>lower than the July 30 Update. The revised forecast mainly reflects<br/>weaker-than-expected results for ICBC, BC Hydro and BC Rail.* At $625 million, the forecast allowance remains unchanged from the<br/>first Quarterly Report because significant risks and uncertainties<br/>still exist.* The estimated one-time pension accounting gain resulting from joint<br/>trusteeship increased by $126 million due to updated actuarial<br/>valuation information.* The provincial debt forecast has increased by $180 million since<br/>the first Quarterly Report and is up $428 million from the July 30<br/>Update. Debt is forecast to total $37.2 billion by year-end, up $3.4<br/>billion since the start of the year.  * Taxpayer-supported debt will increase by $3.2 billion to finance<br/>    the forecast deficit, as well as capital spending of government<br/>    and its taxpayer-supported agencies.  * Self-supported debt will fall by $429 million, mainly due to a<br/>    $712-million reduction in warehouse program debt.DEVELOPMENTS SINCE THE JULY 30 UPDATE  SUMMARY ACCOUNTS                                                         ($ millions)Summary accounts deficit  July 30 Update                     (1,500)First quarter developments:<br/>CRF revenue changes  mainly lower energy revenues  (190)<br/>CRF spending changes  forest fire-fighting savings   25        (165)<br/>Crown corporations  larger losses primarily for ICBC           (191)<br/>Forecast allowance  increased allowance for forecast<br/>uncertainties                                                   (125)Summary accounts deficit  first Quarterly Report forecast    (1,981)Second quarter developments:<br/>CRF revenue changes<br/>* higher prior-year income tax assessments partially offset<br/>  by lower social service tax collections            365<br/>* lower energy and other natural resource revenue   (383)<br/>* other changes                                      (44)<br/>                                                     (62)<br/>CRF spending changes  forest fire-fighting and<br/> other savings                                        31         (31)<br/>Crown corporations<br/>* BC Hydro  lower net income                       (175)<br/>* BC Rail  change from net income to net loss      (119)<br/>* effect of provincial loan guarantee payments for<br/>  Skeena Cellulose Inc and other changes             144        (150)<br/>Joint trusteeship  increased one-time benefit due to updated<br/>actuarial valuation                                              126Summary accounts deficit  second Quarterly Report<br/>revised forecast(1)                                           (2,036)(1) Excluding the one-time joint trusteeship gain, the forecast<br/>    deficit would be $3,442 million.MORE TO FOLLOW</p><p>HOMEX urn:contentItem:4P7G-YGB0-TXN5-R2GB-00000-00REGULAR SHORTS1987-05-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESBriefsPg. 20REGULAR SHORTS

UKRAINIAN KGB HEAD STEPS DOWN

MOSCOW, Friday: The head of the KGB security police in the Ukraine has retired after a scandal over the false arrest of an investigative journalist, according to the local newspaper.

The latest edition of Pravda Ukrainy to reach Moscow said Mr Stepan Mukha, who held the post since 1982, had taken a pension and been replaced by Mr Nikolai Golushko. - Reuter

CHINA FLOOD TOLL 114

PEKING, Friday: The death toll from floods in south China has risen to 114 as far to the north fickle winds threaten to revive a giant forest fire that has twice been pronounced beaten. - Reuter

SCHOOL BUS SHOT AT

BELFAST, Friday: An unknown gunman fired several shots into a school bus loaded with children but the driver was able to manoeuvre out of the ambush without harm to the children, police said. The bus driver was hit in the leg by a bullet during the attack in Strabane, 104 kilometres west of Belfast. - AP

SIRHAN PLEA FAILS

LOS ANGELES, Friday: Sirhan Sirhan, below, imprisoned 18 years ago for the assassination of Senator Robert Kennedy, has lost his ninth bid for freedom. A three-member parole board made its unanimous decision after 90 minutes of deliberation. - AP

EX-INDIAN PM DIES

NEW DELHI, Friday: The former Prime Minister Mr Charan Singh has died aged 85, the Press Trust of India reported. Charan Singh was Prime Minister of the Janata (People's) Party Government for only 24 days in 1979 before resigning rather than face defeat in a no-confidence vote. - Reuter

WIFE WINS VOTE

PEKING, Friday: Students at Peking University who elected the wife of a disgraced academic to a district assembly said today they voted for her because she would dare to speak out like her husband did. Election officials said Ms Li Shuxian received the highest number of votes in the Haidian electoral area, composed mostly of students. She is now a deputy to the district people's assembly. - Reuter

BILL LIMITS TRIALS

BUENOS AIRES, Friday: The Argentinecongress acted today to quell military anger over human rights trials by passing a bill that will sharply limit them. The Senate passed the bill by 23 votes to four, following the chamber of deputies' approval of the bill on May 16. - Reuter

33 DIE FROM WINE

HONG KONG, Friday: Thirty-three people died and more than 6,000 people were poisoned after drinking methanol sold as white wine in the Guangxi province, a report said today. - AP

Port: Sirhan Sirhan

Pg. 18</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Australia bid to change its UN alignment</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>TRUMAN G</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">AUSTRALIA yesterday initiated a push to change its official United Nations alignment with Western European powers to an Asia-Pacific grouping.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Under the present UN Regional Group System devised during the Cold War era, Australia was in the 27-member Western Europe and Others Group, a lobbying body and sometime voting bloc increasingly dominated by European Union nations.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Foreign Affairs Minister Alexander Downer said yesterday the regional groups should be based on geographical lines, and he would seek the support of other nations to overhaul the current system.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>"We are not being prescriptive about how these groups are to be restructured," he said.</p><p>"But from Australia's perspective, a long-term objective would be for a group to be created which is more consistent with our geographic location rather than us being in a group which is increasingly dominated by the European Union."</p><p>Mr Downer denied that being in the Western Europe and Others Group, along with New Zealand and Canada, had disadvantaged Australia's campaign for a Security Council seat last year.</p><p>He noted that Europeans were moving towards a greater unity in foreign policy, meaning other voices could be lost in the crowd.</p><p>"We are at the very beginning of this process and it will take some years to achieve," said Mr Downer, who was yet to consult with Asian leaders about reform of the system.</p><p>"But it's a process that ultimately has to happen, and I think somebody has to promote the process."</p><p>Mr Downer, in New York to address the UN General Assembly today (about 2.30am Queensland time), reiterated Australia's support for calls to ensure the United States paid its arrears to the UN.</p><p>The US administration agreed to pay up to $US800 million ($A1.1 billion) of the estimated $US1 billion it owes the world body, but Congress continues to delay the payment.</p><p>Mr Downer said he would prefer if the US paid back "the full amount, but if Congress were to agree to ($US800 million) that would obviously be considerable progress".</p><p>The Foreign Minister revealed yesterday that Indonesia had initially rejected Australia's offer of help to counter the forest fire crisis in the region.</p><p>Australian fire authorities believed the situation would not have reached disaster stage if they had been allowed to help earlier.</p><p>"Their initial reaction was they thought they could handle the matter on their own; they weren't very enthusiastic initially," Mr Downer said.</p><p>"But as time went on clearly the situation remained bad, even got somewhat worse, and so they came back to us and said yes they would like some help."</p><p>Mr Downer said Indonesia had asked Australia to help about a week after assistance was first offered.</p><p>Earlier this week, Mr Downer hit back at US accusations of unfair trade practices by Australia and signalled Australia's intention to fight Washington on the issue.</p><p>The US accused Australia, South Korea, Japan, the EU and Canada of unfair trade practices, warning it could lead to economic sanctions.</p><p>Mr Downer denied that Australia was in breach of its World Trade Organisation obligations.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4TW0-9880-TXN5-V0HX-00000-00Mummy holds the cards2008-11-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisA248 HoursPg. 5Mummy holds the cardsthe critical guide - CULTURE VULTURELarissa Dubecki

Are mum cards an ace in the hole, or do they make you the joker in the pack, asks Larissa Dubecki.

WITHOUT A DOUBT one of the best things about motherhood, apart from all that unconditional love business, is the licence to start an assertion with the words, "As a mother ..."

Show me a new parent who hasn't thrilled to the emotional payday of playing that trump card over topics as diverse as the environment, global politics and the purchase of a Volvo, and I'll show you a liar also prone to "exaggerate" the truth of little Sebastian's ability to sleep through the night.

The invention of "mum cards", however, will turn that warm inner glow of the truly sanctimonious into a raging forest fire.

Mum cards are an American invention, natch, that have just made their way to Australia. They're business cards for mums, to hand out to other parents, teachers and the like.

"Jane Volvodriver, mother of Charlie and Hunter", for instance. And why not? You could see mum cards as long-overdue recognition that motherhood is a serious business, requiring a degree of commitment well beyond a previous incarnation as deputy internal head of corporate affairs in the filing department.

So why do they generate that vaguely ick feeling usually brought on by too much fairy bread?

Considered on their own they might be handy. Should an emergency arise - young Banjo catches a glimpse of commercial television, for instance, or comes into contact with non-organic cotton - your emergency contact numbers are printed there on a colourful piece of laminated card.

But mum cards are like icebergs. There is a hell of a lot going on beneath the surface. Sure, they can be customised with smiley faces and replicas of your ankle-biter's artwork, but there's more than a whiff of anxiety about them.

As Judith Warner's book Perfect Madness: Motherhood in the Age of Anxiety neatly sums it up, modern motherhood is a "widespread, choking cocktail of guilt and anxiety and resentment and regret"; playing Beethoven to foetuses; hyper-managing the kids' schedules into a revolving door of dance (ballet, jazz and tap), soccer, Mandarin, mini-Rembrandt art classes and feng shui for nurseries.

This intense helicopter parenting is a long way from the days when kids were allowed out of the house without an analysis of the educational benefits of a play date with Jacques and a police background check of his parents.

And if we fail? "Our children will fall prey to countless dangers - from insecure attachment to drugs to kidnapping to a third-rate college ..." writes Warner. It's enough to have you reaching for the gin bottle at 3pm, although if anyone from the Department of Human Services is reading this, I swear it only happened once and it was at the end of a particularly trying week.

Dad cards? Don't make me laugh. Just as no bloke at the office is ever asked who is minding his kids, even the moistest, rom-com-loving snag is likely to draw the line at having a dad card in his man-bag.

No, mum cards are part of the toolbox of the supermum. They say the unsayable, albeit with a smiley face. Slap one of those babies down and you're saying: "I'm organised and in control; my children learn Suzuki-method violin and know how to wash their hands before meal times, and if you let one morsel of genetically modified food pass Sophie's lips you'll be hearing from my lawyers."

Mums aren't simply allowed to be. The endless judgement-laden categorising starts with dividing them into stay-at-home mums (read: daytime TV-watching dolts), or working mums (self-centred career bitches). It quickly moves on to breastfeeding versus formula; disposable nappies versus cotton; Fisher-Price versus artisan wooden toys crafted by nomadic herdsmen from Lapland. And mum cards play their part in that, turning mothers' groups into power meetings; play dates into mergers and acquisitions.

Mums of Australia, it is important to resist this trend towards the corporatisation of day-to-day life, even if it means sticking to arrangements half-remembered through a haze of sleep deprivation and hazarding a guess whether a visiting child was allergic to peanuts or corn chips. Mum cards might be cute and all, but they aren't to be taken lightly. Their vague utilitarian benefits aside, it's only a short stumble to one of those Mum's Taxi signs. And as a mother, I think that's a path best avoided.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>RIVALS IN TALKS : Serbia power grab as fighting rages</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">BELGRADE - Serbian and Croatian leaders last night prepared to attend peace talks despite increased tension caused by fierce fighting and a Serbian move to grab federal power.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Serbia moved to consolidate its control over what remains of Yugoslavia on Thursday, announcing that it was taking over the near-defunct federal parliament.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> A senior Western diplomat said the move effectively dissolved the eight-member federal presidency, which nominally controls the Serb-dominated Yugoslav army.</p><p>The Serbian decision was condemned by Macedonia which, like Croatia and Slovania, has declared its independence and Bosnia-Hercegovina, where Croats and Moslems live in growing tensions with Serbs.</p><p> The army, which launched a major assault against Croatia this week, bombarded areas around historic Dubrovnik, starting a raging forest fire, and closed in on the Croatian capital of Zagreb.</p><p>Croatian leaders say the attacks on the Adriatic, on the eastern Croatian region of Slavonia and in Banija, south of Zagreb, represent a bid by Serbia to define a "Greater Serbia" that would cover most of Yugoslavia.</p><p> The republic of Slovenia and what remained of Croatia would then be permitted to become independent.</p><p> In Belgrade, representatives of the federal presidency from Montenegro, Serbia and Serbia's two provinces decided to take over the federal parliament at a meeting that included the defence minister and army commanders.The presidency normally requires five votes for any decision, but its chairman, Stipe Mesic of Croatia, was not among those at the meeting.</p><p>Croatian President Franjo Tudjman and Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic were reported to be heading to The Hague, where peace talks sponsored by the European Community continued.</p><p> Serbs and Croats share a language and other cultural traits but have been rivals for centuries and enemies during World War II, when fascist Croats killed hundreds of thousands of Serbs and Serbs retaliated on a smaller scale.</p><p> Present Serb-Croat tensions hinge primarily on opposition by Croatia's Serb minority - 12.2 per cent of the republic's 4.75 million people - to living in an independent Croatia.</p><p> Zagreb television reported Croatian forces had been pushed back to within 12km of the republic's capital, after losing several villages to federal fighters.</p><p> Serb rebels and federal troops were advancing north along a wide front in the Banija region, encountering little resistance from retreating Croat troops, according to Belgrade Radio.</p><p> Meanwhile, Yugoslav navy warships closed off Dubrovnik, an international tourist attraction that has been without water, power or telephones for three days.</p><p> Other Croatian ports have been blockaded and the federal navy has warned maritime traffic to stay out of the area.</p><p>AP</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4P0N-JXF0-TXN5-S32B-00000-00Heat, wind recipe for `real bad day'2003-01-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Heat, wind recipe for `real bad day'VICTORIAAngela O'Connor, Chris Evans with AAP

Firefighters in Victoria's north-east are bracing for another day of extreme conditions, with a total fire ban declared statewide today.

The focus has turned from direct attack on the fires to containment as strong winds continue to fan blazes that have swept across more than 65,000 hectares of bushland.

Department of Environment spokesman Mike Leonard said fires around Mount Bogong, Mount Feathertop, Mountain Creek, Bald Hill and Razorback merged overnight on Saturday.

Another fire, in the Pinnabar area south of Corryong, had linked up with blazes burning across the border in the Kosciuszko National Park.

Mr Leonard said firefighters were preparing for worsening conditions, with strong westerly winds and temperatures in the high 30s forecast for today.

But he said he was confident property owners would be ready if fires threatened private land.

"We've had 10 days to get ready for this," he said. "Landowners have been making sure their houses are sealed up, fire breaks along their fences are in check and their pumps work."

Work is also continuing to protect alpine resorts at Hotham, Mount Buffalo, Dinner Plains and Falls Creek.

"They've managed to withstand three difficult days and we're hoping that will continue to be the case," Mr Leonard said.

But Mount Buffalo fire incident controller Peter Novotny forecast wind speeds of 30 to 40 kmh, gusting up to kmh, would make "a real bad day".

A wind direction change to the south-west is expected early tomorrow but without any significant drop in temperature.

"Fires can spot over one ridge top, over valleys to another ridge top," Mr Novotny said.

Thirteen New Zealand firefighters with specialist forest fire knowledge arrived yesterday to help relieve exhausted fire crews, who enter their 13th day of battling the blazes today. "They'll assist us with their skills, providing some expertise and fresh energy," Mr Leonard said.

The army has also responded to the State Government's call for help by assembling a contingent of 100 reservists and 14 vehicles.

Four army convoys are expected in Myrtleford today, with reserve soldiers expected to help prepare fire breaks and containment lines and assist in backburning operations so that professional firefighters can get on with fighting the flames.

Yesterday Metropolitan Fire and Emergency Services Board inspector Ron Haines said the service's Canberra counterpart had declined its offer of help.

"We understand that they have instead deployed crews from the New South Wales Fire Brigade," he said.

"We in Victoria are preparing to face a pretty bad crisis ourselves over the coming week."

Country Fire Authority deputy chief officer Craig Lapsley said more than 50 community briefings had been held recently to prepare residents.

Residents of the Ovens and Kiewa valleys are among those who have been on high alert for days watching what one called "a river of fire" flowing between the ridges around their towns.

Les Maggs lives in picturesque Wallace Lane, Porepunkah. Yesterday he was watering his garden and drenching the weatherboard house where he lives with his wife and son.

The Buckland Valley fire front was one kilometre away, invisible in the thick smoke. He did not know whether it would approach in 10 minutes or two hours.

He was staying to defend his property, but if the worst happened they could stand in the 30 centimetres of water in the Buckland River a few metres away until the fire passed.

Farmer Mark Wallace, whose cattle property abutts the river, listened as trees fell and flames flared on the other side. He was ready last night to put out more spot fires. -- with AAP

Photo: Residents at a house between Ovens and Porepunkah on the main road to Bright watch as the bushfire in Mount Buffalo National Park edges closer. PICTURE: JASON SOUTH. Map.

urn:contentItem:459N-JJ60-0197-T439-00000-00<published>1999-07-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:20Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Crunch time for out-of-form Cats</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>MARK STEVENS</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">GEELONG veteran John Barnes yesterday admitted he was fearful of the fall-out if the club's losing streak stretched to 10 against lowly Collingwood on Saturday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Barnes described the significance of the Shell Stadium clash as "bigger than you believe . . . huge".</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "It's time to break the shackles; if it's not done this week we're just kidding ourselves," Barnes said.</p><p>Asked to predict the reaction to another loss, Barnes replied: "I'd hate to think. It's something you don't want to look forward to."</p><p> Barnes and former captain Barry Stoneham, two of several senior players under scrutiny as Geelong attempts to snap its worst losing streak for 27 years, yesterday spoke out on the club's plight.</p><p> A loss to the Magpies would almost certainly transform embers of discontent into a forest fire at Geelong.</p><p> "Most of the young blokes are probably just playing to keep their spots," Barnes said.</p><p> "Once you start playing to keep your spot, you're probably doing the team no justice."</p><p> Stoneham, in the final year of a contract and striving to play on next year, said the Cats had to loosen up.</p><p> The 31-year-old said Saturday's match was "important as far as the whole club is concerned".</p><p> "I think we've really got to put the other games into the background and go for it this time," he said.</p><p> "It is crunch time for all players.</p><p> "The losing grand finals were rough but this has gone on for a longer period."</p><p> The Cats have lost nine of their past 10 matches at home.</p><p> Their only win at Shell Stadium this year came by six points against Melbourne in the third round.</p><p> Barnes, who at 30 is also in the final year of a contract, said a dearth of fun was a key factor in the Cats' crash.</p><p> "If the boys can stick together and have some fun instead of worrying about their positions, I think we'll be better for it," he said.</p><p> "All it is is deadset fun and getting that bloody monkey off our back.</p><p> "Get some kicks, have some fun with the boys. Just get back to being like a kid when you used to enjoy footy.</p><p> "That's what it was all about; fun and nothing else. I think a few of the blokes have lost that."</p><p> The Cats won their first five matches, but crumbled after a spate of injuries, suspensions and poor form to senior and younger players.</p><p> Barnes said the Cats had to get back to the "quality touches" which were a feature of their early season run when the "pressure wasn't on".</p><p> Barnes, whose patchy form has raised questions about his future, said he was desperate to continue with the Cats next season.</p><p> "I'm out of contract in eight weeks so I've just got to try and get myself physically right and finish off the year on a positive note," Barnes said. Inconclusive video footage freed Port Adelaide midfielder Roger James at the AFL tribunal in Melbourne last night.</p><p> James was reported for striking Collingwood's Scott Burns during last Friday night's MCG encounter but was found not guilty.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4599-TCS0-0197-D51P-00000-00<published>1999-06-10T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:20Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Cole Commotion</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">lloyd cole</p><p nitf:lede="true">THE COLLECTION</p><p nitf:lede="true">(Mercury)</p><p nitf:lede="true">The rock'n'roll survivor is still going strong. And this new offering</p><p nitf:lede="true">mixes his best with the Commotions and his solo career with two new</p><p nitf:lede="true">tracks.</p><p nitf:lede="true">If you're a fan, this is an album not to miss. Many of the popular</p><p>numbers are here to get the toes tapping and memory revived.</p><p>The album starts with top Lloyd Cole and the Commotions tracks from</p><p>the '80s: Are you Ready to be Heartbroken; the catchy Perfect Skin;</p><p>the brooding Forest Fire; the toe-tapping and much-lauded</p><p>Rattlesnakes; and the rollicking Lost Weekend.</p><p>Next the album swings into the '90s with solo Cole's upbeat Undressed,</p><p>the quirky She's a Girl and I'm a Man and Like Lovers Do.</p><p>Winding up the album are the two new tracks, showing typical Cole</p><p>magic. Fool You Are is a rhythmic, up-tempo number while That Boy is</p><p>energetic but questioning.</p><p>Karen Porter</p><p>zebrahead</p><p>WASTE OF MIND</p><p>(Sony)</p><p>Hip-hop party tunes crossed over with grungey guitars seems to be the</p><p>flavor of the month in America at the moment. And Zebrahead doesn't do</p><p>much wrong in its endeavors to get its foot in the door of mainstream</p><p>success. Although its front cover and the dreadful band photo on the</p><p>back sleeve had me initially shuddering at the prospect of reviewing</p><p>some hideous Matchbox 20-wannabes, I was greatly surprised by the</p><p>quality and creativity of this album. The rapping is clever and funny,</p><p>the bass lines are funky, the guitar riffs are chunky, and the</p><p>choruses are catchy and singable. Even the occasional singing is in</p><p>tune! Incredible! Whenever the songs are in danger in becoming</p><p>repetitive, Zebrahead (terrible name, isn't it) will slow things down,</p><p>speed up or break down into a jazzy Latin-flavored jam. Waste of Mind</p><p>certainly isn't a waste of money. It's a great party album that will</p><p>have you bouncing around the room like a red cordial-crazed toddler.</p><p>Michael Owen-Brown</p><p>vonda shepard</p><p>BY 7.30</p><p>(Sony)</p><p>She's better known as the blonde artist singing in the bar on weekly</p><p>episodes of Ally McBeal. With this new release, Vonda Shepard shows</p><p>she has much more to offer.</p><p>Shepard has written, composed and co-produced most of the tracks on</p><p>this album.</p><p>By 7.30 follows hot on the heals of last year's release Songs from</p><p>Ally McBeal featuring Vonda Shepard. But in this release, Shepard</p><p>shows a change of pace in the tracks and an almost poetic and</p><p>meaningful boast with her lyrics, which are mostly about</p><p>relationships. For example, she croons "I feel like a can, I kick</p><p>myself down the street, I'm crushed for a while, Then I get on my</p><p>feet" in the quirky title track Mercy. The standouts of this 13-track</p><p>offering are the piano tunes oozing with emotion about life's road of</p><p>love, such as Cross the Bear and Soothe Me.</p><p>This is Crazy Now and the duet with Emily Saliers of the Indigo Girls,</p><p>Baby, Don't You Break My Heart Slow, also are good numbers. The duet</p><p>is a remake from Shepard's self-titled debut album. Don't expect the</p><p>upbeat TV singer on this album as it's more moody with a slower tempo.</p><p>Karen Porter</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:589W-S9B1-F0NT-H554-00000-00The debt jubilee: an Old Testament solution to our financial crisis?2013-05-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisThe debt jubilee: an Old Testament solution to our financial crisis?SmartCompany

Is there a dramatic and simple way out of all this? Some argue that there is: a "debt jubilee". Drawn from the Old Testament book of Deuteronomy (http://bible.cc/deuteronomy/15-1.htm), the concept derives from the biblical injunction for a day of rest one day out of every week, a "sabbath" day that reflects the teaching the God rested on the seventh day after creating the world in six.There is another injunction for a sabbath year every seventh year, in which people are to not work and on the year after the seventh of those sabbatical years , i.e. the 50th, (one year after the 49th) there would be a jubilee year (   http://www.ewtn.com/Jubilee/history/OT2.htm) during which any slaves would be emancipated and everyone would return to their land and family to live off of natural providence. A clear implication of this teaching is that all obligations, including debt obligations, would be forgiven in the process.The jubilee year is a moral and religious issue concept, not an economic one, and was not practised in actual fact (   http://www.ewtn.com/Jubilee/history/OT3.htm). However, it has been an inspiration to the modern debt jubilee movement (   http://moderndebtjubilee.blogspot.com/p/about.html), which drops the religious context but makes political and economic (and to a degree moral) arguments for extinguishing all or at least some of the debts the world is currently drowning in.The main economic justification for a modern debt jubilee is simple.

With debts forgiven, governments, households and individuals could spend the money currently devoted to interest and principal repayments on consumption which would, in turn, increase economic demand and encourage economic growth, and eventually take the world economy out of constant crisis.This would also be an ethical policy, which lifts debts incurred through financial manipulation (such as unscrupulous mortgage bankers) and undue political influence (such as taxpayer bailouts of banks that caused the crisis in the first place). It would be fairer than the current arrangement, in which current debt largely burdens poor people with repayments falling to rich and culpable individuals and institutions.Two basic questions arise: is a debt jubilee really a new idea, and would it work?There is some precedent for debt relief as a solution to economic crisis. Perhaps the most famous example was the campaign launched by U2 rock star Bono to provide debt relief to developing countries (http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1799103.stm). Bono was a major public face of a coalition called Jubilee 2000, which managed to get the G8 group of major economies to commit to write off $100 billion in developing country debts to developed nations. The idea has similar foundations to the current debt jubilee movement, except it is much more narrow in focus.Private markets also deal regularly with situations where a debtor can no longer repay debt, technically referred to as a default. In those cases, a debt workout (   http://stats.oecd.org/glossary/detail.asp?ID=5929) may be instituted which may include a stretching out of payments, forgiveness of parts or all of the debt by lenders, or even an outside infusion of capital to the indebted party to help them keep current with payments (the major way in which the European Union (EU) is dealing with public debt crises in Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain).So private lenders often forgive debt but, unlike a jubilee, this is not out of goodwill. The intent is to get as much of the loan repaid as possible, even if this might be injurious to the borrower or the larger economy.So there is a precedent for debt forgiveness. But would the widespread and broad application of such forgiveness as called for by the modern debt jubilee movement actually work?The experience of developing country debt forgiveness (   http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/africa/jan-june05/debt_6-13.html) suggests that forgiveness there did have the desired effect of freeing up resources in low-income countries which could then go to more pressing development needs. However, some resources thus freed up got wasted anyway and an argument was also made that forgiving loans frittered away by government merely encourages such recklessness in the future. This certainly could be a risk for a modern debt jubilee.Also, a blanket debt jubilee within the developed world would be much bigger, touching the greater part of the world economic, financial and monetary system. Applied globally, a big issue is that one person's debt is another person's asset. While a debt jubilee would cancel the burden to the borrower, it also would eliminate the value of the debt as source of wealth to the lender.Imagine if all Greek government debt was cancelled. The Greek economy would be better off, but all the banks who made the loans could well be wiped out.This is the main reason why the EU is going to such great lengths to bail out Greece, rather than eliminate or allow a debt default there. There are ways to avoid this problem, especially if central banks printed special money (   http://www.zerohedge.com/news/modern-debt-jubilee) to give to debtors specifically to pay back debt, a form of cancelling the debt without actually eliminating it as an asset to the lender. However, inflationary pressures and other monetary distortions would certainly come along with that solution.It is also argued that defaults and bankruptcies, while painful, do clear out unproductive actors in the economy, clearing the way for more dynamic businesses to take their place, much in the way that a forest fire destroys older trees to make way for new ones. Japan's 'zombie economy' (   http://www.economist.com/node/16847828?story_id=16847828) is often pointed to as an example of how a debt jubilee could make the economy worse in the long run.While Japan never instituted an actual debt jubilee, it has had almost zero interest rates for a long time, making debt repayment obligations minimal and allowing inefficient "zombie" companies to drag along, locking out more entrepreneurial potential (a concern, by the way, being expressed about current central bank policies of very low interest rates around the world). It is indeed plausible that a widespread debt jubilee might lead to the same sort of outcome on a global scale.So is a debt jubilee the answer to our woes - a providential gift, so to speak? From an economic perspective, the answer is likely to be no - at least for a full version of it. However, there might be an argument for targeted debt forgiveness or at least lenient and well-ordered bankruptcies containing forgiveness in especially acute cases.And in many ways, a debt jubilee is said to be more ethical or moral than current arrangements. Which may very well be true, just not necessarily always economically sound.Cameron Gordon is an Associate Professor of Economics at the University of Canberra and has an ongoing appointment as a Principal Investigator at the University Transportation Research Center (Region 2) in New York. urn:contentItem:49MJ-T8G0-01S8-G3KP-00000-00<published>1990-11-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:20Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>STATE A BLISTERING INFERNO</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>ROSS D</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">State a blistering inferno Army on standby as risks increase ] By DAVID ROSS ARMY units were put on standby last night as thousands of volunteer and regular fire-fighters continued to battle huge blazes which have burnt out 10 percent of Queensland. Rural Fire Services inspector Mr Bob Burke said the whole of Queensland was on a ""very high" fire risk level with worsening conditions expected at the weekend. ""The forecast for Saturday is for 35 degrees throughout the state with strong north-west winds," he said. ""That spells even more trouble if the public do not play their part in not lighting fires." Queensland Forest Service teams were called in yesterday with their graders and bulldozers to help contain a huge fire burning out of control in 3000ha of state forest about 10km north of Gatton. Senior fire-fighters described the forest fire as ""spectacular". Hundreds of fire-fighters were keeping a close watch on several major ""out of control" fires in the Great Dividing Range, east of Warwick and Allora on the Darling Downs. The fires, most of which started last Saturday, have been classified as serious. At Builyan, north-west of Bundaberg, a number of fires are threatening grazing land and state forests. In the Eidsvold Shire, which has had a total fire ban since Tuesday, two major fires broke out but were contained last night after an extra 130 fire-fighters and eight brigades were called in from surrounding districts. The army fire-fighting unit at Enoggera was being kept informed on an hour-to-hour basis of the situation of the Gatton and Warwick region fires.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>In New South Wales at least 200,000 sheep and 140,000ha of grassland have been destroyed by fire during the past 24 hours. Two men also are recovering in Griffith Base Hospital after being burnt while fighting the season's first major fire, near Hay. Bushfire Council spokeswoman Ms Anne Gittins said Rod Scott, 16, had received second-degree burns to 20 percent of his body, and Paul Snyman, 31, had second-degree burns to 15 percent of his body. Both are now in a stable condition. She said the fire, which began 35km south-west of Hay about 10.30am yesterday, was under control. Ms Gittins said it was being contained within a perimeter of several hundred kilometres. More than 300 local townsfolk, farmers and fire-fighters from Sydney and surrounding districts worked through the night to bring the fire under control. Fire-fighters were helped last night when winds turned the fire back on itself, preventing it burning further east to Darlington Point, near Griffith, and Coleambally, near Wagga.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P8H-NRS0-TXN5-S1N1-00000-00Greatest risk lingers on rim of old volcano1997-01-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Greatest risk lingers on rim of old volcanoCounting The CostLEITH YOUNG

People living in the Dandenongs are on an extinct volcano. And in echoes of the ancient past, the homes at greatest risk of burning in fires are those on the rim of the old craters.

These buildings face on to steep slopes covered with trees. When a hot wind drives a bushfire up the slopes, it gathers strength and speed, consuming almost anything in its path.

A Shire of Yarra Ranges spokesman, Mr Brian Littlechild, said this was basically what happened on Tuesday.

"If you went three of four streets back from the edge of the ridges, you wouldn't know there had been a fire," he said.

In hot, dry conditions, the Dandenongs are a tinderbox. It is mainly highly flammable ash eucalypt forest and south-east Australia is one of the four most fire-prone regions in the world.

A blaze pushed by the weather dries everything in its path, creating its own fuel. Even cool fern gullies will dry out ahead of a forest fire and burn like straw.

Fires this year might be worsened by good wet seasons in the past two years, which have built up the leaves, bark, branches and other vegetation litter on the forest floor, Mr Littlechild said.

It was also evident that some home owners did things that fuelled the fire, such as keeping tall trees beside houses.

"There is no law that says you cannot have trees a metre from your roof line, which is all very lovely, but it does make it hard in a fire," Mr Littlechild said.

The Department of Natural Resources and Environment, which looks after the forested public land, can back-burn and reduce the litter at the edges and along tracks.

"But they can't burn off the whole forest, it's against the nature of this sort of forest," he said. "People come here for the forest."

The chief fire officer for the department, Mr Gary Morgan, said his department had not cut back on fuel reduction burns or on slashing.

The biggest restriction from year to year was weather, not budgets, and the number of days suitable for fuel reduction burns.

Mr Littlechild said new residents quickly learnt about fire danger and what to do to minimise risks. Local laws insisted that they clear vegetation litter from their properties, and owners could be served council notices if they failed to comply.

After a big fire, the pattern was that residents who had lost property often moved. A new wave of people without experience of fires moved in and the cycle started again.

One resident who asked not be named said there was one way to live in the Dandenongs. "Build a cheap house, insure it, take all the precautions but expect to be burnt out every 10 years."

For inquiries about the safety of relatives: 03 9686-8333

urn:contentItem:6FNN-3DR3-RWMW-P3B0-00000-00Dangerous trees being felled after forest fire in inaccessible location2025-04-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:19ZLexisNexisDangerous trees being felled after forest fire in inaccessible locationKatrina Lovell

The blaze burnt about an acre of land.

Fire crews were called to a blaze in an inaccessible part of the Framlingham Forest on Saturday, April 26, 2025.

A Country Fire Authority spokesperson said the fire started about 1.12pm which burnt about one acre near Purnim.

He said it was in an inaccessible part of the forest, and bulldozers had been called in to fell a number of dangerous trees as a result of the fire.

A fire investigator attended the scene on Sunday, April 27, 2025 to help determine the cause of the blaze.

Fire crews were also called to reports of a grass fire along the Cobden Warrnambool Road at Naringal East on Sunday.

But when they arrived on scene it was a tree on fire and it was extinguished within about 10 minutes, the spokesperson said.

urn:contentItem:3W60-8YM0-0048-T3KS-00000-00<published>1999-04-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:20Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>World News In Brief</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CHINA FIRES</p><p nitf:lede="true"> BEIJING, April 6 AFP - Twenty-three people have been killed fighting a serious forest fire raging across a vast area of mountain woods in northern China.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Some 1,000 soldiers and firefighters are battling the fire with help from 2,000 civilians, the official Xinhua news agency said in an overnight report.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The blaze started in the mountains bordering Fenyang city in northern Shanxi province on Saturday and spread to neighbouring Wenshui county the following day.</p><p>AFP</p><p>US SUBWAY</p><p> NEW YORK, April 5 AP - A man who has said ghosts inhabit and control his body is mentally fit to stand trial on charges he killed a woman by pushing her in front of a subway train, a judge has ruled.</p><p> Judge Carol Berkman ruled today that Andrew Goldstein, 29, can understand the charges and court proceedings and help his lawyer present a defence.</p><p> Goldstein told police and psychiatrists that voices told him to shove Kendra Webdale, 32, and that an irresistible "ghost" or "spirit" took control of his body just before the push.</p><p> The judge said the state's standard for finding a person mentally fit is "not particularly high" and Goldstein, who has a 10-year history of mental illness, is "not so impaired that he cannot participate in his trial".</p><p>AP</p><p> CHINA COLLAPSE</p><p> BEIJING, April 6 Reuters - Eight boys were killed and five injured when a school toilet block collapsed in China's central Jiangxi province.</p><p> The China Education Daily reported today that 30 boys were in the block at the Wangqiao school for 12 to 18 year olds when the roof and walls collapsed on April 1.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p> CHINA POISON</p><p> BEIJING, April 6 Reuters - A Chinese court has sentenced a restaurant owner to death for poisoning the donkey soup at a nearby rival and making 148 people ill.</p><p> The Workers' Daily reported today that owner Chi Jianguo and employee Zhang Zhanguo, jealous of the good business the competitor enjoyed, hired Wang Chunli and three other farmers to throw poison into the pots as the donkey soup cooked.</p><p> Chi's death sentence was suspended for two years. Such sentences, given to allow time for repentence, are usually commuted to life imprisonment.</p><p> Zhang was sentenced to life in prison, while the three farmers were jailed for six to eight years, and Wang is still at large.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p>JAPAN ENDANGERED</p><p> TOKYO, April 6 AP - One in five Japanese travelling abroad say they have bought traditional medicines made from endangered species, a government survey showed today.</p><p> But most of the 172 people questioned said the drugs were purchased as "rare souvenirs" and that they had seldom been consumed, according to the Environment Agency survey.</p><p> They were asked whether they had ever bought traditional medicines made from parts of eight species - tigers, rhinoceroses, bears, musk deer, deer, sea horses, fur seals and pangolins.</p><p> Drugs made from bear parts were particularly popular, with 139 people saying they had purchased them.</p><p> International trade in the eight animals involved, as well as products made from their parts, has been banned under the Washington Convention.</p><p>AP</p><p> INDON LANDSLIDE</p><p>JAKARTA, April 6 AFP - Three people were killed and another was missing after a landslide crushed their house on the Indonesian resort island of Bali on Sunday.</p><p> The state-run Antara news agency reported today that the landslide was in Bangli district, 75 km north-east of the island's main city of Denpasar.</p><p> Several landslides in Bali's mountainous interior in the past months have killed more than 40 people.</p><p>AFP</p><p> ENDS WORLD DATELINES    <br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1999</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3W60-8YM0-0048-T3KS-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-26</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="603"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1999 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P8H-NS70-TXN5-S17T-00000-00rosteredDAYOFF1999-02-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisSATURDAY EXTRAPg. 2rosteredDAYOFFThe weekend's best...Emma Walker with Frances Atkinson

Dance

First Bonehead, then fleshmeet, now Bodyparts - what, exactly is Chunky Move trying to say? The answers lie with choreographers Gideon Obarzanek and Lucy Guerin. Individually, they have produced an impressive body of work; but this time, as special guests of the Melbourne Fashion Festival, they have created works for each other. Both perform in solo pieces in a program that includes group performances by the hard-working team Chunky Move. All is revealed as audiences go indoor and hardcore at the CUB Malthouse, South Melbourne. Tonight at 8pm (also 22-27 February before touring regional centres). Tickets: $35/$18; bookings: 13 6166 or 9685 5111.

Performance

The familiar image of the "mad" woman in the attic extends beyond the pages of Victorian novels; in fact, there are all-too-real instances of women being incarcerated at Sunbury for reasons of "criminal insanity" (reasons now known as postnatal depression and menopause). Performer, director and teacher Karen Martin explores the history of the Sunbury Lunatic Asylum in a performance event which delves into the lives of the women forced to live there. The Women's Jail Project is on tonight at 8.15pm (plus 25-27 February) in the Women's Refractory (adjacent to Victoria University's Sunbury Campus,

The Avenue, Sunbury). Tickets $25/$20; bookings: 9744 2291. A free shuttle

bus runs between North Melbourne station and Sunbury, leaving at 7.30 pm.

Theatre

Go Wilde. The final in a trilogy of plays by David Hare focusing on English society and the nature of love explores the witty and wearying world of Oscar Wilde. The Judas Kiss (directed by Neil Armfield and featuring Bille Brown as Wilde) concentrates on two particularly traumatic moments in Wilde's life; the day he decides to stand trial for "acts of gross indecency" and the night his lover Bosie (Lord Alfred Douglas) betrays him. Opens tonight at 8.30pm (plus Monday 6.30pm, Tuesday-Friday 8pm, matinees Wednesday and Saturday at 4pm) until 20 March at the Victorian Arts Centre's Playhouse theatre. Tickets: $28.95-$46.95; bookings: 13 6166.

Fashion

Fashion gets a serious dressing down as kids take over the catwalk. Clarks Kids on Parade is a day of free family entertainment and parades by leading Australian children's designers - Chino Kids, Run Scotty Run, Oshkosh and more - revealing the autumn/winter look for cool kids. Part of the Woolmark 1999 Melbourne Fashion Festival, activities take place on the Eastern Lawn, Royal Botanic Gardens (enter Gate B or C) from 2.30pm. The festival continues today and tomorrow; telephone: 9826 9688; bookings: 13 6100 (or visit www.melbournefashionfestival.com.au).

Book

Bittersweet: Contemporary Black Women's Poetry, edited by Karen McCarthy (Allen & Unwin, $24.95) is bursting with voices describing the experiences of black women poets from Britain, Asia, the Caribbean, Africa and Canada. From childbirth to adolescence, death and beyond, the earth becomes a spectacular backdrop to both small and large dramas. The poems are divided into chapters, including: Earth, Blood, Salt, Forest, Fire and Water. No matter what the topic, all the poems possess a certain charge and as a collection, it gives the reader a chance to discover new voices alongside more familiar names, such as Alice Walker, Grace Nichols and Maya Angelou. -- Frances Atkinson

* Compiled by Emma Walker (fax 9601 2587)

urn:contentItem:4P7M-CWB0-TXN5-R2G2-00000-00ADDERGIES? DEY'RE NUDDIG TO SDEEZE AD1990-03-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:19ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 13ADDERGIES? DEY'RE NUDDIG TO SDEEZE ADDAVID GRIMES Source: (Sarasota Herald-Tribune, Florida

I APOLOGISE now for any spelling errors this column may contain; I am forced by allergies to type with one hand while my other hand holds a handkerchief to my nose.

This is an awkward way to live one's life, one hand dangling, the other cupping a damp cloth over the face in the manner of people escaping a forest fire.

"What seems to be the problem?" people ask.

"Addegies," I say through the cloth.

"Huh?" they say.

Garbled speech is not the only handicap of the allergy sufferer. Bank personnel get extremely nervous when you walk though the door with a handkerchief concealing your face. Eating is problematical. Getting dressed one-handed takes twice as long.

Do not tell me to see a doctor. I went to an allergist once and I swore I would never go back.

"What seems to be the problem?" the allergist said.

"By doze is ruddig ad I'b sdeezig," I said.

"I can't understand you with that handkerchief over your face," he said.

"My nose is running and I'm sneezing," I said.

"We need to do some tests," the allergist said. "Take off your shirt."

The next thing I knew, a nurse was rolling in a cart bearing approximately 56,921 tiny syringes. They prick you with these needles to find out what you're allergic to. It's the kind of test that gives you sympathy for what voodoo dolls go through.

It turned out that I was allergic to almost everything.

I was allergic to ragweed, pollen and cats.

I was allergic to grass, trees and dust.

I was allergic to tuna noodle casserole, tomato aspic and Cocoa Puffs cereal.

I was allergic to telephone salespeople, neckties and those subscription cards that fall out of magazines.

I was allergic to management, both the hands-on and hands-off variety. I was allergic to rap music, Christmas shopping and people who signal right and turn left. I was allergic to watches that beep, waiters named Bob and television weatherpersons who say "thunderstorm activity".

I was allergic to irreducible Visa card balances, car mechanics who look under my hood and say "oh-oh", and high school students who think the capital of the United States is New York City.

I was allergic to call-waiting, designated hitters and the words "some assembly required".

I was allergic to hot-air hand dryers, Geraldo Rivera and toy poodles wearing sweaters.

I'm hoping that they come up with a pill that will make all of my allergies go away. In the meantime, however, I expect I'll be doing a lot of sneezing.
