urn:contentItem:805B-49G0-YB64-42N1-00000-00Costs of climate change are already spiralling out of control2010-08-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisBUSINESSOpinion & AnalysisPg. 2Costs of climate change are already spiralling out of controlG-BIZPADDY MANNING

Without action, we can expect a smorgasbord of disasters. YOU don't have to be Lord Stern to see how the costs of climate change are already compounding and spiralling out of control. Some costs are relatively benign - like the devaluation of certain high-priced waterfrontages as sea levels rise - a process starting in earnest whether estate agents like it or not. Other costs are terrible, like the conservative $4.4 billion put on last year's Black Saturday fires by the Victorian Bushfires Royal Commission, including insurance claims of $1.2 billion (property and vehicles), $1.1 billion spent by the Victorian Bushfires Reconstruction and Recover Authority, $658 million in destroyed timber, 173 lost lives worth $645 million according to established formulas (not counting injuries) and about $593 million spent on firefighting (not counting volunteers). Climate change features minimally in the commission's final report, handed down a fortnight ago.

That is interesting in itself, because when he announced the inquiry Premier John Brumby said everything would be on the table, including climate change. The commission's interim report last August was silent on climate change - many letter writers to The Age raised this glaring omission - but flagged the issue would be dealt with in the final report. In September 2009 the commission took expert evidence from CSIRO principal research scientist Kevin Hennessy. He was asked seven key questions, including whether climate change was a contributing factor to the extreme fire weather conditions on Black Saturday, and how often such catastrophic conditions might occur over the next 10-40 years. Except perhaps in the darkest sceptic circles, it is uncontentious that climate change contributed to the dangerous fire weather that day - although Hennessy pointed out that a forensic "detection and attribution" study, as was carried out after the 2003 European heatwave, would need to be done to determine the exact degree of contribution. The commission's final report notes it "took limited evidence on the subject of climate change because it was persuaded by Mr Hennessy's conclusions [which] are consistent with the opinions of the Bureau of Meteorology and CSIRO, Australia's leading climate science agencies". Dangerous fire weather is generally measured by the Forest Fire Danger Index, which takes in temperature, rainfall, humidity and wind speed. The 1939 Victorian bushfires that burnt 1 million acres were given an index score of 100, now called "catastrophic" conditions. In some locations on Black Saturday, the index reached 170 and higher. According to a 2007 study by the CSIRO, the Bureau of Meteorology and the Bushfire Cooperative Research Centre, by Chris Lucas and others including Hennessy, catastrophic days occurred at only 12 of 26 locations across south-east Australia (the triangle below a line from Brisbane to Adelaide) for which good records are available, back to 1973. At four places, the frequency was one occurrence in eight years or less. The study, which formed the basis of Hennessy's evidence to the royal commission, then looked at various global warming scenarios to 2020 and 2050, using low and high greenhouse gas emissions projections. On top of warming of 0.7 degrees to 1990, compared with pre-industrial levels, the "low" emissions projection assumed 0.4 degrees of warming by 2020 and 0.7 degrees by 2050, keeping total warming to 1.4 degrees. The "high" warming projection assumed 1 degree of additional warming by 2020 and 2.9 degrees by 2050, taking total warming to 3.6 degrees. "Given that global warming over the last 15 years has been tracking the mid-to-high IPCC range, the projections for fire weather are more likely to be closer to the high global warming range than the low global warming range," Hennessy says. Cutting to the chase, the scariest numbers are these: by 2020, under the high warming scenario, catastrophic fire weather days will occur at 20 sites, and at seven of those the frequency will be every eight years or less. By 2050, catastrophic days will occur at 22 sites, and at 19 of those the frequency will jump to every eight years or less. So that's catastrophic fire weather occurring at almost double the sites. In Bourke, Ceduna, Laverton, Melbourne airport, Mildura, Wagga and Woomera, catastrophic fire days could occur every three years . . . or less, the expert witness report concludes. These figures predict an increase in frequency of catastrophic fire weather, not fire occurrence, which would be influenced by fuel load, land-clearing and ignition. But the risk is plain. For those who think we're going to hell in a handbasket, Hennessy's figures are a wake-up call. "Low" warming (beneath the so-called 2 degree guardrail) is much safer than "high" warming (3 or 4 degrees, which is where we are heading based on the world's post-Copenhagen pledges). And that's just bushfire risk. The Insurance Council of Australia puts bushfire claims by value at just 7 per cent of natural disaster claims over 1967-1999, smaller than flood (29 per cent) severe storm (26 per cent), cyclone (25 per cent) and earthquake (13 per cent). But those figures are based on a 2001 study, which Hennessy says do not include area burnt or lives lost. As the post-Copenhagen malaise over climate deepens, plenty of people have observed it's going to "take another disaster" - like Hurricane Katrina, say - to drive genuine public concern and action to beat global warming. At the going rate it looks like there'll be a smorgasbord of disasters, with heatwaves from New York to Tokyo, drought and bushfire in Russia and the floods overwhelming Pakistan. But in Australia, after Black Saturday, surely we've had enough disaster already? Paddy.manning@fairfaxmedia.com.au

urn:contentItem:4SRM-KYN0-TXN5-S0PK-00000-00The cost of everyday humanity2008-06-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:19ZLexisNexisA2BooksPg. 33The cost of everyday humanityMEMOIRClaire Scobie

The Open Road

By Pico Iyer

Bloomsbury, $32.95

Pico Iyer's vignettes give a great warmth to one of the world's iconic leaders, says Claire Scobie.

PICO IYER'S FIRST impressions of the Dalai Lama are hazy. He was a disinterested schoolboy when his father insisted that they pay a visit to the deposed leader's home in Dharamasala. What stayed with Iyer, then 17, was a vision of swirling mist rather than the Tibetan monk's conversations on emptiness and reality. That was in 1974, and ever since, Iyer has followed the Dalai Lama's passage "down from the mountaintop".

The Open Road is an account of this enduring friendship. As Iyer travels with Tenzin Gyatso, he explores how exile can bring opportunity. Even though the Dalai Lama still travels on the yellow identity card of a refugee, he views loss as transformative. For Iyer, who in 1990, lost all his possessions, including eight years' worth of books in a forest fire in Santa Barbara, this is deeply instructive.

Pico Iyer, essayist, journalist and accomplished travel writer, portrays the Dalai Lama from three angles - in public, private and in practice. On the international stage, Iyer watches how Westerners project their dreams on to him. In part, because Tibet wears "the contours of a fairytale"; in part, our need for the Dalai Lama to be "an emissary from some other world that doesn't exist".

Yet, the Nobel Peace Prize winner couldn't be more down to earth. He's not in the business of peddling the view that compassion falls from the heavens. It takes hard work. The Dalai Lama starts his meditation at 4.30am every day - and can do it while listening to the BBC World Service.

Iyer notices that the Dalai Lama is frequently dismissed when he speaks in English and is ignored when he talks philosophically. (Most people refer to his "presence and warmth".) He recounts how one Canadian journalist described the Tibetan leader, "as not exactly the brightest bulb in the room". Deliberately, Iyer believes, the Dalai Lama has spent the past two decades compressing millennia of Buddhist teaching into a modern doctrine of simple human ethics. But his "everyday humanity" comes at a cost. No one would dare ask the Pope if "he has dreams of women", yet the doctor of metaphysics is seen as fair game for any question.

So it's startling to be reminded that Tenzin Gyatso is still a student. In a telling detail Iyer recounts how, when the photographer Manual Bauer, who spent more than three years photographing the Dalai Lama - in meditation, weeping, watching TV bare-chested - showed him the photos to check none violated his privacy, his subject questioned only one picture. It seemed to show, because of the perspective, that he was sitting higher than one of his teachers.

Such vignettes give this intimate and insightful portrayal of one of the world's iconic leaders great warmth. Iyer succeeds in de-cloaking the Dalai Lama, showing his many faces, and as with his other travelogues, does so with an excellent eye for detail. His descriptions of Dharamasala, a "wild globalised village", where Tibetan boys "roam around like packs of wild dogs" preying on starry-eyed Western women, and Israeli backpackers seek hedonism and spiritual highs, are spot on.

It is there, among his own people, that Iyer records one of "the most moving moments". Witnessing the Tibetan leader with newly arrived refugees, Iyer describes how "when the Dalai Lama came into the room, it was as if the whole place began to sob and shake".

And this strikes at the core of the Dalai Lama's dilemma. Tenzin Gyatso "serves two constituencies - his own people and the world". The wider community wants him to be "a wise man, sitting above all nation-states and offering global counsel".

Meanwhile, his compatriots are desperate for a solution with China, as the latest wave of unrest in Tibet would indicate. As the exiled leader tries to follow the non-violent approach and still appease the younger generation of frustrated Tibetans, he's caught between a "monk's vision and a guerilla's".

Iyer has no answers. As much as he tries to be an objective journalist, he admits, "Something changed in me each time I left his company, even as I was telling my friends, heatedly, that humans never really change". In a sense, The Open Road tells us as much about the author, his subject, as it does about ourselves. So often in trying to fathom this simple Buddhist monk, people become caught up in the mist. Iyer brings us back into focus.

Claire Scobie is the author of Last Seen in Lhasa, published by Vintage.

urn:contentItem:7YYB-XC01-2RR2-D01M-00000-00Around the galleries2010-07-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:19ZLexisNexisA2Pg. 22Around the galleriesDan Rule

WHAT Bushfire Australia WHERE TarraWarra Museum of Art, 311 Healesville-Yarra Glen Road, Healesville, 5957 3100, twma.com.au THIS exhibition proves a poignant exploration of Australian art's historical and contemporary negotiations of bushfire-related themes and imagery. An extensive collection of historical works fills much of the main space. William Strutt's famed 1864 work Black Thursday, February 6th 1851 sprawls across one wall, vast, dramatic and tempestuous, but ultimately overbearing. The softened hues and atmosphere of Arthur Boyd's Burning Off (1958), J.W. Curtis's Breaking camp, forest fire (1893) and the searing forest landscape of John Longstaff's Gippsland, Sunday night, February 20th, 1898 make for far more evocative examples.

It's a dynamic echoed in many of the contemporary works created in the wake of the Black Saturday fires, which only just fell short of the museum site. While the more violent imagery goes some way to capture the power and brutality of the flames - the towering, billowing smoke of Petra Reece's All consuming and relentless (the beast) is perhaps the finest example - it's the quieter works that perhaps prove the most affecting. Camilla Tadich's compact oils are haunting and mute. They capture unusual perspectives of the devastating aftermath of the blazes that tore through her home town of St Andrews and she fought from her door. Her car headlights shed light on the burnt remnants of a house, car and water tank; daybreak reveals an ashen landscape, drained of movement, colour and life. Peter Wegner's tiny, gestural bronze sculptures - which render victims embracing or alone, in shock in the wake of the fires - are the most unassuming but also the most heart-rending of the collection. Tues to Sun 11am-5pm, until July 25. WHAT Saffron Newey: Serious Moonlight WHERE MARS Gallery, 418 Bay Street, Port Melbourne, 9681 8245, marsgallery.com.au THEORETICALLY, Saffron Newey's darkened, meticulously detailed oils might fit the genre of the landscape painting, but the Melbourne artist's work avoids a palpable sense of representation and place. Painting from her own night-time photography, these works possess an uncanny luminosity. Certain colours glow and shimmer while others are muted in the half-light. Shapes and shadows of the indefinite pervade. Newey's curious vantages - low to the ground, from behind shrubs, foliage and bushes - only add to the arcane atmosphere. Shafts of moonlight splay onto an empty track; the tips of leaves gently radiate against the darkest of blues. We're left with a clutch of starting points, with more questions than answers. From whose perspective are we surveying these scenes? Just where are we and why are we here? Newey feeds us hints and traces while we wander and wonder. Her paintings are evocative starting points to an undefined narrative. Tues to Sun 10am-5pm, until July 31. WHAT Wayne Viney: Radiance WHERE James Makin Gallery, 67 Cambridge Street, Collingwood, 9416 3966, jamesmakingallery.com RADIANCE seems the perfect title for Wayne Viney's latest series of monotype prints. Known for his stunningly blurred, vaporous landscapes, the Melbourne artist and printmaker has abstracted all but a trace of the lay of the land in this series. Rather, he plies these works with simple horizontal phases of light - the ambience, perhaps, of the sun's reflection and refraction from the earth - void of details and topographies. Viney's reductive, nonetheless beautiful prints exude a timbre or resonance rather than a representation. Hue, tone and texture are of the essence. Tues to Fri 10am-5.30pm, Sat 11am-5pm, until July 24. WHAT John Spiteri: Aquaria Humanistica WHERE Neon Parc, Level 1, 53 Bourke Street, city, 9663 0911, neonparc.com.au THERE'S an alluring duality to John Spiteri's mixed-media paintings, prints and assemblages. Though somewhat elusive in their orientation and detail, the works that comprise Aquaria Humanistica don't just present a multifaceted artistic outcome, but grant access to various cryptic stages and chapters in Spiteri's process. Muted grey and brown oil and enamel is rubbed, sanded, cut and drawn upon; figures emerge out of muddy backdrops; repetitions percolate from one work to the next. In many ways, these works feel like archaeological relics from another dimension or era. They are fragmented moments, figures and evidence - they allude to so much while explaining so very little. Wed to Sat noon-6pm, until July 31. WHAT Benjamin Armstrong: Walking backwards to the place I come from WHERE Tolarno Galleries, Level 4, 104 Exhibition Street, city, 9654 6000, tolarnogalleries.com DESPITE their delicacy and lightness of touch, Benjamin Armstrong's hand-blown glass sculptures invoke a kind of poetic sense of permanence; the irrevocable passing from one plane to the next. Taking the form of large, hollow glass orbs - or as he describes them, "corrupted hourglasses" - sitting one atop the other, they appear as if in the midst of funnelling matter from the top to the base chamber. Brown dust, a baguette, a golden fish and a human brain are towed and sucked towards the inescapable lower cylinder, like unwilling specimens. The stunning, large-scale Chinese ink and pigment drawings (below) that accompany the sculptures, however, suggest a different set of possibilities. Using the erupting volcano as a central motif, they seem to show the potential for regeneration and the cyclic. In Permian times a volcano spews forth clouds of smoke, though in Too little too much those clouds spill sparkling rain to the earth. Tues to Fri 10am-5pm, Sat 1pm-5pm, till August 14.

FIVE PHOTOS: Petra Reece's All consuming and relentless (the beast).

urn:contentItem:802J-88V0-YBDY-R2YB-00000-00KEY FINDINGS2010-08-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisWRAPPg. 2KEY FINDINGSNorrie Ross

Norrie Ross analyses the top recommendations from the Black Saturday Royal Commission report

SAFETY POLICY

The state should revise its bushfire safety policy to put the saving of human life at the pinnacle through a range of new policies around warnings, evacuations, planning, honest appraisals of the safety of individual houses and the ability of the people living in them to defend them.

COMMENT: An umbrella recommendation to ensure a suite of practical measures, co-ordinated and well planned, are in place to meet the kind of day that occurred on February 7, 2009.

STAY OR GO

Stay or Go policy should be retained, but with major alterations around warnings, defendability advice and recognition of the vulnerability of the "stay" option for the elderly, infirm and the young. The commission said the policy failed on Black Saturday because it was too rigid, failed to take into account topography and the ferocity of the weather conditions and was not clearly understood by the public.

COMMENT: Although the "stay and defend or leave early" policy failed, and the majority of deaths occurred in or around houses, the retention was inevitable. The only viable alternative was a forced mass evacuation policy and witness after witness said no one would force them to leave their homes. People to be told the "go early"' part of the policy is always the safest option.

FUEL REDUCTION

Fuel reduction burns to be almost doubled based on an annual rolling target of 5 per cent of public land to be burned each year compared with the current target of 1.7 per cent. The DSE to report on the targets, the areas burned, the cost and the impact on biodiversity.

COMMENT: This recommendation addresses the greatest criticism and concern in the bushfire-devastated communities. Lack of roadside clearing meant access roads were "wicks" that brought the fires into towns and lack of clearing over decades increased the forest fire danger index to catastrophic levels.

SHELTERS

Local councils should be helped by the State Government to develop plans in high-risk communities for bushfire shelters and evacuation points. New municipal management plans for hospitals, schools and aged care homes and lists compiled of the most vulnerable residents.

COMMENT: This recommendation addresses a major safety gap for the vulnerable. Establishing a network of community bushfire shelters will be very expensive and the State Government may baulk at the cost and persist with its cheaper policy of "safer neighbourhood places" such as footy ovals.

RESETTLEMENT

The state develop a "retreat and resettlement'' policy where householders in high-risk bushfire areas are bought out and resettled.

COMMENT: The most radical recommendation and potentially enormously costly. The commissioners were clearly troubled by the mountain of evidence of wooden homes built on ridges, homes abutting pine plantations and homes where the only escape route was by a single track dirt road.

EVACUATIONS

The state develop an evacuations policy, especially for vulnerable people and a policy for emergency evacuation.

COMMENT: One of the toughest policies to implement and it is fraught with problems in areas where there are dirt roads, dead ends and evacuation routes are along narrow tree-lined roads.

POWER LINES

Dangerous overhead power lines gradually replaced with underground and aerial bundled cable to reduce the risk of bushfire ignition on high wind days. A timetable of 10 years in the highest risk areas.

COMMENT: Five of the 11 major fires were caused by power lines, but it is estimated burying lines would add at least 20 per cent to power bills. Highly unlikely to be implemented in full, but there will be measures to upgrade power line inspection and replacement of aging cables.

LEADERSHIP

Remove the title of Co-ordinator in Chief of Emergency Management from the Police and Emergency Services Minister and transfer it to Chief Commissioner of Police.

COMMENT: This recommendation removes the political element from emergency management on days like Black Saturday. Police Minister Bob Cameron was savaged for failing to recommend to the Premier that a state of disaster be declared and there is a suggestion the decision was grounded in the politics of the situation.

FIRE SUPREMO

A new independent statutory office of Fire Commissioner to become the new fire supremo for the state. The new Fire Commissioner to report to the Police and Emergency Services Minister and be responsible for increasing the operating capacity of all the fire services, particularly on the highest risk days, and advising of the boundaries between metropolitan and rural firefighters.

COMMENT: A recommendation that might cause resentment in the fiercely independent CFA hierarchy but there was a strong feeling in the commission hearings that no single individual felt they held the responsibility to ensure the state was prepared for the worst fire day.

FIRE LEVY

An end to the fire services levy on insurance premiums. Replaced with a property-based levy with concessions for low-income earners.

COMMENT: For every $100 paid by policy holders, $40 is directed to government taxes, including the fire services levy. Removal would decrease premiums and make people who currently have no insurance pay their fair share.

ARSON

A much higher police focus on arson with a centralised approach to training, prevention, detection and, at a local level, a scaled response in police areas according to the risk of catastrophic fires.

COMMENT: Victoria Police already gives a high priority to bushfire arson but the report's recommendation would mean a more co-ordinated approach with priority given to intelligence gathering and research. And at a higher cost.

** These are the top 11 of 67 findings by the Royal Commission. See key details of the recommendations and other significant findings on P6-7

urn:contentItem:4P7G-YNJ0-TXN5-R2H8-00000-00SMOKE SLOWS RESCUE OF CRASH SURVIVORS1989-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 8SMOKE SLOWS RESCUE OF CRASH SURVIVORSBRAZILSource: The New York Times

RIO DE JANEIRO, Wednesday: Efforts to rescue 46 survivors of a plane crash in Brazil's Amazon jungle have been hampered by driving rain and dense smoke from burning trees, the Air Force Ministry said.

The plane crash-landed on Sunday near Sao Jose do Xingu but it was yesterday before one of the survivors struggled to a ranch and radioed that 46 of the 54 passengers and crew on board had survived and were safe.

Pilots trying to pinpoint the wrecked plane said torrential rain and smoke from burning forest had reduced visibility to nil. At this time of the year many farmers burn the rainforest to extend their ranches.

A ministry spokesman said in Brasilia he hoped the last of the victims would be rescued by today.

Eight passengers died as a belly landing was made by the pilot of the jetliner, a Varig Boeing 737, after the plane ran low on fuel, Brazilian Air Force Ministry officials said yesterday. No foreigners were reported to have been aboard the flight.

On Sunday night, in a final radio transmission, the pilot of the commercial flight said he was lost over the jungle, was flying at an altitude of 8,000 feet on one of the plane's two engines and would try to land guided by the light of a forest fire. After two days of growing anxiety in Brazil, news bulletins broke into television programming yesterday afternoon to report that a survivor, Mr Epaminondas Souza Chaves, had appeared at a ranch in the Alto Xingu region in the eastern Amazon.

Speaking to civil aviation authorities by amateur radio, Mr Chaves is reported to have said that he first walked to another ranch but that it had no contact with the outside world. It is not clear how far the ranches are from the crash site.

"The passenger said that all the survivors are in good health and that the crew of six survived," an Aeronautics Ministry spokesman said in a telephone interview from Brasilia. The ministry later reported, without giving details, that several people on board had been injured.

By nightfall yesterday, four other survivors reached the ranch and a Brazil Air Force Hercules cargo plane dropped food, water and medicine to the remaining survivors at the crash site, the spokesman said.

With machete-wielding workers hacking a trail through the jungle, medical teams set out last night by foot to the crash site, about 1,780 kilometres north-west of Rio de Janeiro. Helicopters were due to fly to the site today.

urn:contentItem:55BV-3R11-F0J6-J072-00000-00Alphabet soup of regulators thickens2009-06-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 17Alphabet soup of regulators thickensMiddle way - NEW LANDSCAPEAnthony Hughes NEW YORK

US President Barack Obama says he wants US banking regulators to see the forest as well as the trees when it comes to guarding against another meltdown of the financial system.

But given the abject failure in the build-up to the credit crisis to notice the forest fire raging before them - and the Federal Reserve actually feeding the fire with its low interest rate policy from 2001 to 2003 - getting them to see the bigger picture by detecting systemic risks will be easier said than done.

The central premise behind the reforms is that regulators will be able to stop the next bubble before it forms and bursts painfully, but history shows regulators never keep up with financial innovation.

For instance, the reforms promise tighter regulation of credit default swaps - the financial instrument responsible for the collapse of American International Group - but it is conceivable that banks will be able to create other instruments to "manage their risk" that will escape the attention of regulators.

Typically it is only in hindsight that it becomes clear how dangerous such products were. And even if regulators do identify products that are considered risky, it is not entirely clear what they would do about it.

Still, the direction of the reforms that Obama and the Treasury Department have outlined are hard for most to quibble with, given the events of the past year, though exactly how far-reaching they will really be is a topic for debate.

It is at least noteworthy that despite assertions that Obama's reform agenda has been significantly watered down from its original lofty goals, they proved meaningful enough to attract a negative response from the banking industry when Treasury's 85-page White Paper was released on Wednesday.

Luckily for Wall Street, the legislative process is likely to be slow-moving and lead to many changes that could dampen the negative impact for banks.

Coincidentally, nine banks given bail-out cash last year paid it back on Wednesday and some, such as Goldman Sachs, have used that event to issue a public mea culpa and promise better behaviour.

That may also be a sign that banks are about to step up their PR efforts to mould the final reform legislation and make sure it doesn't crimp their profits as much as many fear.

What is striking is that many of the reforms outlined in the white paper already seem to have involved compromises to try to maintain a degree of regulatory status quo.

A blueprint for reform outlined more than a year ago by former Treasury secretary Henry Paulson (notably before the climactic events of September) focused on rationalising the number of overlapping regulators, but the new administration looks to have largely abandoned that idea.

For instance, some say the decision against merging the Securities and Exchange Commission and Commodities and Futures Trading Commission (the merger would have combined regulation of stocks and futures and other derivatives) was based on preserving the power of the separate congressional committees that oversee each body.

The regulators themselves have lobbied hard to protect their own turf and ensured much-needed rationalisation of the "alphabet soup" of regulators was kept to a minimum. In fact, the alphabet soup is expanding with the creation of a Financial Services Oversight Council (FSOC) and a National Bank Supervisor (NBS).

The FSOC is the body that, along with the Fed, will hopefully be able to identify systemic risks. But exactly how it will do this seems so vague that it calls into question what difference it will make.

The NBS brings together the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Office of Thrift Supervision. and will be the prudential regulator of federally chartered banks.

There are many state-chartered banks and the aim will be to harmonise regulation so banks can shop for the best regulatory environment. But it may prove difficult to get all states to co-operate.

Another element of the package is making sure issuers of asset-backed securities have a 5 per cent interest in the securities they issue.

This seems to imply that securitisation was also to blame for the crisis, yet securitisation was around long before the housing bubble emerged and proved an important means of expanding the availability of credit to the economy.

After all, it is hard to forget banks lost hundreds of billions in the past year from holding these securities on their balance sheet, so having a financial interest may not make such a big difference - and could actually add to risk in the sector.

As for implications for Australia, foreign banks in the US will face the same rules as local banks. It was already clear there would be tighter requirements globally on banks, as the red-faced Basel Committee looks at overhauling the way it assesses how much capital banks should hold to guard against losses.

Stressing the need for international reform also may put more pressure on politicians around the world to reflect on their own regulatory inadequacies.

urn:contentItem:3T5F-1Y30-0048-T1CH-00000-00<published>1998-07-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:20Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>WORLD NEWS IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MEXICO POVERTY</p><p nitf:lede="true"> MEXICO CITY, July 14 AFP - Some 26.3 million Mexicans, representing more than one-fourth of the country's population of 95 million, lived in extreme poverty, Social Development Minister Esteban Moctezuma said today.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The new figure increased from 24 million registered a few months ago, Moctezuma said, in a meeting with officials at the National University.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> According to various non-governmental organisations, the number of Mexicans classified as living in simple poverty, now exceeds economic crises.</p><p>AFP</p><p> US THONG</p><p>HOUSTON, Texas, July 14 Reuters - Six women wearing thongs (G-strings) demonstrated in favour of scanty bathing suits on the steps of Houston City Hall today as scores of Texan men, barking like dogs, indicated their support.</p><p> "I'm doing this for women's rights and everyone's rights," personal trainer Polly Keller, 36, said, wearing a bright yellow thong.</p><p> The protest was spurred by cancellation of a planned thong contest in a city park after City Councilwoman Martha Wong complained it was not proper use of public property.</p><p> About 200 people, 98 per cent of them men, were at the demonstration, while police on horseback and on foot stood by but did not intervene.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p>IRAN PRESS</p><p> TEHRAN, July 14 DPA - The publisher of an Iranian tabloid newspaper was barred from work for three years for publishing indecent pictures, the Tehran press reported today.</p><p> Ali-Mohammad Mahdavi-Khorami, publisher of the daily Gozaresh Ruz (Report of the Day), was also ordered to pay a fine of $ US4,000 ($ A6,520.00) by a Tehran court for publishing "illegal and indecent pictures".</p><p> The daily had printed a picture last month in which a young Iranian was shown flirting with a girl. The headline was: "Meeting … under the shadow of fear".</p><p> DPA</p><p>GREECE FIRE</p><p> ATHENS, July 14 AFP - A forest fire broke out today at a village near Olympia, the scene of the original Olympic games and one of Greece's most important archaeological sites.</p><p> It did not pose an immediate threat to inhabitants or the treasures, Greek officials said.</p><p> The blaze occurred at the village of Vassilaki, east of Olympia but firemen were able to stop it spreading to houses.</p><p>AFP</p><p> US MAYAN</p><p> NEW YORK, July 14 AFP - Thirty-two Mayan relics are the prize in a legal tug-of-war between Guatemala - which says the objects were stolen - and Boston's Museum of Fine Arts, which has refused to return them.</p><p>Guatemala hired attorneys after the museum officially refused on June 26 to return the items to the Central American nation, Guatemala's consul here, Fabiola Fuentes Orellana, said yesterday.</p><p> The relics - cups, figurines of people, and jars - have been on display since December, when the museum opened new galleries devoted to art from Oceania, Africa and Pre-Colombian Americas.</p><p> The museum received the artefacts from benefactor Landon Clay in 1988 and they were part of its permanent collection, it said.</p><p>AFP</p><p>ETHIOPIAERITREA</p><p>ADDIS ABABA, July 14 AFP - Italy has donated $ US100,000 ($ A163,000) worth of food and medicines to aid Ethiopians displaced by the border conflict with Eritrea, state radio announced today.</p><p> The gift is expected to cover the needs of 100,000 people for three months, the radio said, citing a communique from the Italian embassy here.</p><p> The money will be channeled through the World Health Organisation "to contribute to the efforts made by the Ethiopian government to improve conditions for displaced civilians," the radio said.</p><p>AFP    ENDS WORLD DATELINES<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-02-28</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="598"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4DGC-Y5R0-015G-Y2JH-00000-00<published>2004-10-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:20Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>CARSGUIDE; Pg. C08</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Hard charger for enduros</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Wolter Kuiper</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">WHILE that loud Yank, Harley-Davidson, was blowing out the candles on its 100th birthday cake last year, Husqvarna was also celebrating its centenary.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The quiet Italian (yes Italian since 1987) can claim to have led the recent four-stroke off-road revolution with its lightweight machines but for many years built V-twin road bikes just like Harley.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Its first modern-era four-strokes were based on Husqvarna's traditional two-stroke single crankcase but the engine in the latest TE510 enduro machine is definitely state of the art.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Thanks to its move from Sweden to the MV Agusta SpA factory at Varese, the Husky also gets the best in Italian components. There are Marzocchi upside-down forks, a Sachs remote reservoir shock, Magura hydraulic clutch, Brembo brakes and Polisport plastics.</p><p>The switch gear and alloy rims are, appropriately, Japanese.</p><p>Fitted with an alloy rear subframe, the TE is much slimmer than Husky's old twin-pipe four strokes. The tank is anorexic at just 7.7litres, fine for enduro competition but a bit light-on for extended rides in the Australian bush. The seat is narrow and almost dead flat, perfect for weighting the front end.</p><p>It comes off with a single quick-release fastener and then the battery, which powers a tiny starter motor, flips out of the way for air filter access.</p><p>The test bike was fitted with Aussie Barkbusters, which are well worth the bucks for bush riding.</p><p>The rest of the plastics already appeared a bit second-hand, although there was less than 1000km on the tiny digital speedo, with the rear mudguard looking as if it had been loved by someone's boot buckles.</p><p>But the Michelin Enduro Competition rubber was definitely brand new.</p><p>The Husqvarna TE510 is not a play bike, unless you like playing with fire.</p><p>It's a machine designed to be ridden hard in enduro competition and will pummel you if you don't keep up the pace.</p><p>The carburetion on our test machine was super clean, as crisp as fuel injection. With minimal flywheels the Husky lights up extremely quickly.</p><p>We spent a few hours on forest fire trails where the 510 could be opened up and there was a margin for error.</p><p>It could even have handled a smaller back sprocket.</p><p>Gear changes need to be made rapidly, as the Husky builds up speed thanks to the way it builds revs and the close transmission ratios.</p><p>The steering is quick and the handling is beautifully neutral -- lean forward to unload the back tyre and tighten your line, lean back to unload the front wheel over rocks.</p><p>A particularly gnarly downhill off-camber corner was no longer a worry on the TE510.</p><p>The Brembos stopped us taking out an echidna and several kangaroos doing the same to us.</p><p>On another tight and bumpy single forest track it wasn't near as much fun. Here it was stalling repeatedly, wishing for a lower first gear or better skills.</p><p>The self-retracting sidestand started to be a real pain.</p><p>Given a decent amount of throttle the Husky had no trouble climbing the snottiest hills. It also loved the wet, loamy soil and bermed corners.</p><p>At a motorbike park we decided the 510 must have been set up for a heavy bloke with small feet. How did we know? Well we missed a few shifts in the lower gears because the gear change lever needed to be a touch higher and the whoops on the expert circuit needed to be approached at speed to make the suspension work at its best.</p><p>We tried backing off the compression damping but the suspension was still very stiff.</p><p>This is a great bike for enduro "special tests" -- much firmer at both ends than the Yamaha WR450 we tested last year -- but most riders would probably prefer suspension that's more progressive.</p><p>HUSQVARNA TE510</p><p>Engine: 501cc DOHC four-valve four stroke</p><p>Transmission: Six-speed constant mesh</p><p>Price: $12,490</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:7YM0-9NF0-YBDY-R277-00000-00MANY MUST SHARE THE BUSHFIRE BLAME2010-06-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 14MANY MUST SHARE THE BUSHFIRE BLAMETONY CUTCLIFFE

The commission wasted a rare chance to make Victoria safer for next time

THE Victorian bushfires royal commission ended in farce. With virtually unlimited terms of reference it was entrusted to get to the bottom of the Black Saturday catastrophe and help avoid a repeat episode. It has done neither.

Instead of examining a compound failure of complex systems, the inquiry led an evidentiary monologue aligned with its untested preconceptions formed at the outset. The inquiry's only departure from mediocrity was its relentless isolation and degradation of selected individuals in the absence of logic or natural justice.

The tedious humiliation of former Country Fire Authority chief Russell Rees went well beyond the need to establish the facts. The calculated mortification of former police chief Christine Nixon made Victorians cringe. The idea that a colossal systemic failure can be sheeted home to a couple of individuals is a dangerous fantasy.

The commission maintained a myopic focus on the events of Black Saturday, divorced from a long history of causality. The commissioners appeared to be little more than spectators observing the intellectual bravado and superficiality of counsel assisting. Ironically, given its findings, no one at the commission appeared to be in charge.

The commission needed at least to try to understand the complex systems that lie beneath big bushfire episodes. Apart from the cost to human life, large wildfires threaten Victoria's water supply and its electricity distribution network, hydro-power generation, communications trunks and transport infrastructure. And if Victoria's forest fire emissions last year had been subject to a carbon levy the bill might have reached $5 billion.

Indeed, when probability is added to the scale of destruction, uncontrolled bushfires pose a greater threat to national security than terrorism. The terror threat was met correctly with urgency and a big investment in world-class technology, training and practice. By comparison, Victoria's worst bushfire disaster has been greeted with a dog and pony show.

A savvy royal commission would have placed political and practical decision-making front and centre in its deliberations.

It would have called on experts in behavioural psychology, system dynamics and cognitive leadership. The inquiry could have uncovered the influences behind decisions that now can be seen as fatally flawed.

It could have resisted pointless adversarialism that has sent potentially productive insiders ducking for cover.

A successful inquiry would not have allowed fuel reduction levels to become an ideological dispute. It could have calculated the risk radius around settled areas and determined how much forest maintenance was required to keep those areas safe.

The commission focused on improving the maintenance of antiquated electricity distribution networks, which is simply putting lipstick on the same old pig. The cost of replacing obsolete technology could have been justified by an assessment of economic benefit to communities from a larger and more reliable energy supply.

The commission has insisted on portraying CFA volunteers as a homogenous and sacrosanct group of heroes. In fact, the quality of the volunteer base has been diluted by an influx of urban cowboys who cannot be allowed anywhere near a fire for their own sake and that of their communities. These volunteers would be far more productive and cost effective if their value were appraised realistically and their efforts directed to forest maintenance that reduced fire risk.

Decentralisation of authority is also required to allow communities to leverage their intimate local knowledge and experience. Internet technology could be used to enable locals to share intelligence and updates in real time and prevent the hopeless inundation of the triple 0 centres that occurred on Black Saturday.

Unfortunately, the commission glossed over the need for communities to accept greater responsibility for their own safety. While growing hordes of tree-changers enjoy the scenery, it comes with serious risk that is compounded by complacency. There are vast areas that are too riddled with risk to support safe habitation and that reality can no longer be ignored.

External organisations such as 774 ABC radio need to recover the editorial independence that waned under the mantle of ``emergency services broadcaster''. The publicly funded broadcaster must scrutinise government agencies, but it blurred the line between observer and participant.

If they had had the humility to seek a role model, the commissioners should have looked to the Stretton royal commission conducted after Victoria's 1939 bushfire disaster.

Justice Leonard Stretton completed his inquiry in just four months and provided a safety prescription that served Victoria for 40 years.

Instead, public agencies are being exhorted to deliver urgent and radical improvement while also being required to wait patiently for the royal commission to unfurl its ponderous conclusions. Equally worrying is the absence of any fitness test applying to the commission's recommendations, including flops such as the Code Red community warning system.

This same system had already been tried and had failed miserably in the US after 9/11, but the royal commission did not do its homework.

Tragically, the royal commission has wasted a generational opportunity to recalibrate the entire chain of responsibility involving an increasingly populated, highly forested urban interface.

It had the chance to reinvest communities with resilience, self-sufficiency and meaningful leadership opportunities.

It could have helped communities to create mechanisms to cope with heatwaves, floods, epidemics and other crises that are as certain as they are unpredictable.

The royal commission could have hallowed the fire grounds with a world-class model of social, environmental and economic innovation. Instead, the mountain laboured and delivered a mouse. Consequently, hundreds of lives lost or wrecked on Black Saturday have been devalued by pomposity and self-aggrandisement of truly catastrophic proportions.

______________________________

>> Tony Cutcliffe made a submission to the royal commission and is a director of Melbourne community forum the Eureka Project

urn:contentItem:4D9M-01X0-015H-53VC-00000-00<published>2004-09-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:20Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FINANCE; Pg. 41</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Bizzy Bits</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Marshall Hall</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">*****DUDLEY Quinlivan has scored another coup.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Mr Quinlivan, who earlier this month sold a giant 8638sq m amalgamated apartment site in Broadbeach to high-rise king Harry Triguboff for an amount said to be around $33 million, has offloaded another,  albeit less valuable, potential  development site.</p><p nitf:lede="true">This time it is in Main Beach.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Remi Lane, a company associated with Mr Quinlivan, has sold a 1034sq m double block on the corner of Hughes and Tedder avenues.</p><p>According to sales records the site was purchased by a company owned by Rob Dale, who heads up corporate training and motivation group Speak Corporation, for $2.85 million.</p><p>Remi Lane bought the site 15 months earlier for $2.35 million.</p><p>The site comprises 29 Hughes Avenue and 32 Tedder Avenue with two older-style homes.</p><p>The amalgamated site, at the northern end of the Tedder Avenue restaurant and shopping strip, was previously earmarked for a residential and commercial redevelopment.</p><p>******KEN Lacey, the multi-millionaire milkman, and his wife Madeleine, are showing plenty of commitment to their  efforts to help son Lace Italiano advance his  rap career.</p><p>The couple, who have an $18 million price tag on their Hedges Avenue house, apparently signed up  to sell their penthouse in the Sonata tower building even before they had settled the purchase.</p><p>The Laceys agreed to splash out a cool $2.6 million for two units in Sonata, at 20 Queensland Avenue, Broadbeach. The deals were $1.45 million for a three-bedroom, one- bathroom unit penthouse that came with three car spaces, and $1.15 million for another three-bedroom apartment in the same complex.</p><p>The couple purchased the two apartments in two separate deals signed in January and settled in July.</p><p>However, the penthouse was put back on the market in June, more than a month before the purchase was finalised.</p><p>*****TREVOR Chappell and Edgar Hung, the head honchos at developer Austcorp, are doing so well with their Coomera Waters Village and Resort estate that they have apparently attracted a likeable copycat.</p><p>If it's not tiresome enough to be hauled through the courts by one of Australia's richest men - Bob Ell - in relation to its investment in a Kings Forest property, it appears another smart operator hopes to ride on the coat-tails of Austcorp's Coomera Waters dev-</p><p>elopment.</p><p>The $500 million, 1500-home Coomera Waters Village and Resort is growing like a forest fire, and where's there's fire there's always a bit of smoke.</p><p>Former Sydneysider Robert Profilio, who has been in the real estate game for 33 years, has adopted the name Coomera Waters Real Estate for his Southport based operation.</p><p>He registered the business name in January 1999 - about 27 years after Austcorp registered the company Coomera Waters Estate.</p><p>Austcorp apparently took steps - including a trip to the Office of  Fair Trading - to stop Mr Profilio from using the name.</p><p>However, all that came to no avail and Mr Profilio, who says he now has close and friendly working relationship with Aust-corp, hopes to move his office into the estate within six months.</p><p>****ANDREW and Greg Bell, the brothers who head up the multi-award winning Ray White Surfers Paradise, are certainly not feeling like taking a slowing real estate market lying down.</p><p>While Real Estate Institute of Queensland figures released yesterday show that Gold Coast property prices fell 5.3 per cent in the June quarter - the largest fall in the state - the Ray White team are on the expansion path.</p><p>As well as substantially beefing up the number of sales people at the Orchid Avenue office, the company is spreading its presence in the Hope Island area.</p><p>And now Andrew, who, as well being a dab hand with a gavel, acts as the organisation's chief executive, has signed a deal to buy a small Main Beach rival.</p><p>From next month Realty on Main, a six-year-old agency that was started by Jody Green, will be no more.</p><p>Ms Green said that when she started the agency there were three real estate operations in the Main Beach area.</p><p> "Now there are seven."</p><p> Ms Green said she sold the rent-roll of 50-60 blue chip properties for 'a good price', but would not go into the details.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier C20</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Light on how fires behave</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Asa Wahlquist</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FIREFIGHTERS battling the NSW bushfires do so armed with knowledge built up by science. Later this year firefighters and land managers will have the results of significant new research to assist them.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> CSIRO senior principal research scientist Phil Cheney says researchers are working to understand how fires behave.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>"We try to use that knowledge to devise prediction systems, assist firefighters in their training programs, and make recommendations to authorities on things like what distances are needed to set back from bushland and how to manage the fuels in bushland," Mr Cheney said.</p><p> Research in the past has concentrated on understanding low-intensity fires, such as those used for hazard reduction.</p><p> The CSIRO has been working with the WA Department of Conservation and Land Management for the past six years on Project Vesta, studying high-intensity fires like those that have raged in NSW since Christmas. And it has produced some surprises.</p><p> "We are finding that there is an interrelationship between the amount of fuel and the wind speed which we didn't appreciate before," Mr Cheney said.</p><p> Vesta researchers have found that the Forest Fire Danger Meter, now used to estimate fire speed, can dramatically under-predict the potential rate of a fire's spread.</p><p> In forests where there is a shrub layer over one metre tall, fires can spread up to three times faster than predicted by the danger meter, while fires in forests with litter and a low shrub layer can spread two times faster.</p><p> In the past, fire researchers thought fire increased continually with wind speed, but research has shown there is a "stepwise" process.</p><p> "There tends to be a threshold wind speed which has to be exceeded before a fire will develop to its full potential."</p><p> This means a slight jump of wind speed, to around 12 to 15 km/h, can result in a big jump in fire behaviour.</p><p> "One of the really important findings of our last research was how fast a fire moves after a wind change, particularly on relatively small fires," he said.</p><p> The head of a fire burns in the shape of an ellipse, with narrow ends and broader sides. "We hadn't appreciated that the width of the head fire is an important factor in determining the speed of the fire. It may be burning well below its potential rate of spread simply because it is narrow," Mr Cheney said.</p><p> "This is a phenomenon which occurs in high winds. A fire may be a long, narrow tongue. Then when the wind changes it immediately spreads at its (faster) potential rate of spread (from the broader side)."</p><p> A fire starting from a line 100 metres long will burn at its potential speed immediately.</p><p> This finding defied the old belief that a fire goes through a growth period, building up speed.</p><p> "We found out that this was not so," he said. "It moves immediately away at its potential rate of spread, and we believe this was a contributing factor to several of the entrapments over the last five years."</p><p> The results of project Vesta are still being analysed. They will result in new guidelines, the National Fire Behaviour Prediction System for dry eucalypt forests, later this year. The new guidelines will help land managers make better decisions about hazard- reduction fires.</p><p> "When these severe conditions break out there is a tendency to say 'well, they are totally unpredictable'," Mr Cheney said. "We think that … when we have worked through this we will do a better job."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Soft policing allows Borneo to burn free </nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">POOR law enforcement is fostering the spread of forest fires in Indonesia, with blazes spreading from plantation and timber concessions to virgin forests and bushland, firefighters claim.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Plantation and timber companies have frequently been blamed for the blazes enveloping East Kalimantan province, although the companies have denied responsibility for the fires, which are blanketing the area with choking smoke.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The more than 1000 fires now burning across the province are out of control, although non-governmental organisations and the authorities are doing their best to deal with the problem, the German-funded Integrated Forest Fire Management Project says in a report released at the weekend.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AFP</p></bodyText></section><p>"Despite these efforts, the fire situation in East Kalimantan has escalated to an extent that extinguishing the fires is far beyond any suppression capabilities," it adds.</p><p> "Several large fires have been burning in forest conversion and concession areas for weeks, and though the provincial Government is very serious about handling the situation, law enforcement still seems too weak and too slow to get them under control."</p><p> Experts using satellite imagery have said many of the fires in East Kalimantan are burning in timber and plantation company concessions, where they are being used to clear land for fresh planting, but only a few have been charged.</p><p> The report adds that Indonesian authorities are pursuing ineffective strategies to counter the fires which have left thousands ill, at least one dead and more than 130,000ha razed in the province in recent weeks.</p><p> "Unfortunately, there is also a strong tendency to expensive high-tech solutions -waterbombing, use of retardants that have little or no effect as long as infrastructure and firefighting capacities on the ground are deficient," says the report, from the group's headquarters in the provincial capital of Samarinda.</p><p>Indonesian authorities have launched cloud-seeding, waterbombing and other initiatives against the fires in recent weeks but concede they have been unsuccessful. A recent helicopter flight over the stricken area had alarmed officials and was driving new efforts to counter the fires, the report says.</p><p> Hundreds of soldiers and civilians have been deployed against the fires, which are mainly concentrated in the Kutai national park and Bukit Suharto forest, respectively north and south of Samarinda, where visibility has fallen as low as 50m in recent days.</p><p> The fires have heightened fears of a repeat of last year's devastating haze, when blazes in Indonesia blanketed much of South-East Asia in choking smog. Brunei last week ordered schools closed for at least two weeks because of the haze.</p><p> Reports in Jakarta, meanwhile, said the forest fires had razed 42 houses near Samarinda, leaving 330 people homeless. No casualties were reported but a number of people were arrested for looting as firefighters battled the blaze, the Jakarta Post said.</p><p>UN experts are reportedly on their way to Jakarta to help Indonesian authorities combat the fires.</p><p> Fires have also been reported elsewhere in Kalimantan, Indonesia's section of Borneo island, and on the island of Sumatra but they are said to be under control. Forest fires were also raging in The Philippines' western island of Palawan.</p><p> Reports on Saturday said 27 forest fires have been raging on the Palawan peninsula, whose vanishing virgin forests host some of the world's most endangered animals. The reports quoted officials as saying the fires covered 1500ha of forest.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P6W-1CJ0-TXN5-R2KM-00000-005000 holidaymakers flee inferno2002-01-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 15000 holidaymakers flee infernoRobert Wainwright, Sarah Crichton, and Stephanie Peatling

About 5000 tourists and residents fled houses in one of the State's favourite summer holiday playgrounds last night and huddled on a point, trapped between two national parks and the sea.

A massive fire swept through Sussex Inlet, 250 kilometres south of Sydney near Jervis Bay, destroying up to 12 houses and blocking the only road out.

About 500 people took to the beach while others huddled inside the bowling club and the RSL club, which was turned into a makeshift hospital to treat people suffering from panic and respiratory problems.

A Channel Nine helicopter pilot told the Herald last night that he had been forced to escape the area because of poor visibility but that it appeared that fire had engulfed a school.

The nearby hamlets of Cudmirrah and Berrara were evacuated about 5pm and residents headed to Sussex Inlet before the town came under threat as the fire was fanned by strong westerly winds.

The crisis struck so quickly that firefighters did not have time to arrange back-up crews before roads to the south were closed. Instead, 50 firefighters were rushed in from Wollongong to aid the desperate house-to-house battle in 65kmh winds.

Last night, there were fears that the fire could turn again, and head toward Jervis Bay to the north.

The Rural Fire Service Commissioner, Phil Koperberg, said the fierce winds were largely responsible for the destruction, but reinforcements had also been held up by road closures caused by other fires to the south.

"We have got reinforcements in from the north but they're experiencing firestorm conditions, the situation is very, very intense," he said. "All of the 75 aircraft dedicated to the firefighting effort statewide were fully committed to protecting property elsewhere."

In another emergency evacuation, at least 26 people, including 11 children and 10 police officers, had to be airlifted out of Colo Heights, west of Wisemans Ferry, by three helicopters in the face of a fire which threatened to engulf the fire station.

Further south at Bowen Mountain, about 500 people were evacuated after the fire which threatened Kurrajong Heights on New Year's Day flared again in gusty conditions.

Elsewhere on the verge of Sydney, firefighters grappled with a limited water supply to contain a forest fire which began in the Holsworthy Military Reserve and jumped Heathcote Road into the Sandy Point and Pleasure Point residential areas, threatening dozens of homes. The fire burnt out five hectares before being brought under control.

Another fire in East Ryde's Field of Mars Cemetery was also brought under control.

Mr Koperberg nominated the Blue Mountains blaze as potentially the most serious confronting firefighters as 100 fires continued to burn around the state.

But despite the last-minute emergencies, fire authorities last night were confident that weather conditions were turning in their favour for the first time in more than a week, describing today's outlook as promising, but still critical.

While no rain is forecast, conditions for fire-fighting are expected to improve slightly as temperatures drop into the high 20s and winds ease and turn to the south-west.

In other developments:

*The Premier, Bob Carr, said juveniles caught lighting fires should be made to take part in justice programs, including facing their victims and paying compensation, rather than going to jail.

*The NSW Coroner, John Abernathy, launched an inquiry into the causes of the fires.

* Mr Carr and the Prime Minister, John Howard, announced they would consider buying up to four big firefighting helicopters, worth $15 million each.

* Community fire units in Sydney's north-west were praised for helping to save hundreds of homes threatened by fresh outbreaks in Pennant Hills Park.

MAP: Princes Highway cut, 5000 people from Sussex Inlet and Cudmirrah evacuated onto beach.

urn:contentItem:44RY-J3M0-015G-P216-00000-00<published>2001-12-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:19Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES-TYPE- OBITUARY-COLUMN- OBITUARIESTIME AND TIDE-BIOG- DINO GROLLO; Pg. 13</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Matriarch built solid home life</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Robert Pascoe</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Obituary</p><p nitf:lede="true">Dina Grollo</p><p nitf:lede="true">Italian-Australian community leader.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Born Melbourne, December 12, 1942.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Died Melbourne, December 3, aged 58.</p><p nitf:lede="true">THE group of families whose surname is a household word in the Australian construction industry has lost one of its leaders.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>Dina Grollo, the wife of construction magnate Bruno Grollo, took an active interest in the life of the Grollo company and the success of the firm owes a great deal to her nurturing capacity. When Bruno Grollo faced charges in 1997 relating to a federal police inquiry into the company's tax affairs, for which he was later acquitted, Dina urged him to trust their sons Adam and Daniel with more of the day-to-day running of the firm, which has built some of Australia's most prominent buildings. These include the Rialto Tower, Melbourne's tallest building; the $500 million Eureka Towers apartment complex at Southgate; and the 53-level Bloomberg-Grollo tower in Brisbane.</p><p> "She gave me a lot of encouragement and she was always by my side when there were problems," Bruno Grollo says. "I always discussed business with her, it was a family thing. I don't think she liked the long hours but she put up with long hours for the sake of letting me satisfy my ego."</p><p> Dina Grollo's family, the Bettiols, came from Cusignana, the same township on the Treviso plain in Italy from where the Grollos came. Cusignana is an old agricultural community and many of its people emigrated. They took with them a capacity for honest hard work, an ambition to succeed and a strong co-operative ethos.</p><p> One of the Bettiols, Cesare, immigrated to Australia in the late 1920s and worked alongside Luigi Grollo, the father of Bruno and Rino, in the forests of Gippsland.</p><p> Like Luigi Grollo, Bettiol moved to Melbourne after the disastrous forest fire of 1939. He and his wife, Luigia Marchiori, settled in the suburb of Thornbury, where the Grollos later moved from Carlton in the '50s.</p><p> The Bettiols' daughter Dina first worked as a shop assistant at Woolworths before going to work in the office of the nascent Grollo building company as a young woman. She married Bruno Gordano Grollo in Melbourne on March 27, 1965.</p><p> As the family business grew from humble suburban concreting to the construction of skyscrapers, the wives of the Grollo men were closely associated with the work of the firm.</p><p> Dina Grollo was an accomplished homemaker, providing a loving and consistent family structure. The family regularly enjoyed camping, picnics and skiing, and Dina, whose passion was photography, lovingly documented the family's growth and development.</p><p> During the '90s the Grollo firm established itself as a leading builder in Sydney, taking its reputation for large-scale construction to the national stage. But tragedy struck when Bruno Grollo was charged with conspiracy. Dina was by his side in court every day.</p><p> She suffered a stroke during this ordeal, only to come back to the court a few months later in a wheelchair. On June 26, 1997, Bruno and his two co-accused were acquitted of conspiracy to pervert a federal police investigation into the company's tax affairs. The Grollo brothers won their final court case on November 28 last year, when an alleged $25 million tax fraud was dismissed.</p><p> Dina Grollo will be remembered as a kind and loyal person. She had a modesty and gentleness of spirit that was a great resource for those around her, especially her exuberant husband.</p><p> She is survived by Bruno; their daughter, Lee-Anna; sons Adam and Daniel; and six grandchildren.</p><p>Robert Pascoe, dean of arts at Victoria University, is the author of four books on the Grollo family</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:3SD3-X6X0-0048-T4XJ-00000-00<published>1998-04-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:20Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>UN MAY USE AID RECIPIENTS TO FIGHT FIRES IN INDONESIA</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ll <emphasis typeStyle="it">d </emphasis></p><p>nv</p><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, April 6 Asia Pulse - UN Environment Program (UNEP) executive director Klaus Topfer has concluded a two-day visit to Indonesia by saying that agencies would meet later this month to develop a coordinated response to Indonesia's forest fire disaster.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The United Nations is considering using recipients of food-for-work programs to fight the catastrophic bush and forest fires ravaging the country which have caused a direct economic loss of up to $ A2.44 billion.</p><p nitf:lede="true"><emphasis typeStyle="it"> Satellite pictures show at least 1,000 hotspots concentrated in East Kalimantan, with lesser fires burning elsewhere on the island of Borneo. </emphasis></p><p>There was an urgent need to prevent the fires spreading to other parts of Indonesia, Topfer said.</p><p> Fires blazed across several islands of the archipelago from July last year until late monsoon rains put out most of them.</p><p> However, the prolonged El Nino-influenced drought which has been particularly evident in parts of Kalimantan has fuelled fires once more this year.</p><p> "These problems this year are very early," Topfer told a media conference here.</p><p> "So that is a very negative signal. If we have the ongoing drought, that will be a very serious prognosis."</p><p> The fires were linked with climate change and had global consequences, with the carbon dioxide emissions estimated to be equivalent to the annual CO2 emissions from all of Europe, Topfer said.</p><p> "I really believe this is a real catastrophe for the people," he said.</p><p> "It is a disaster with regard to the economic consequences … and it is an environmental disaster."</p><p> The fires were one of a hit-list of problems facing Indonesia at the moment and, in conjunction with the UN Development Program (UNDP), the UNEP had come up with a proposal to combine efforts to tackle the food shortage - the food for work programs - with firefighting efforts.</p><p> If the program gained approval at a Geneva meeting of concerned agencies on April 21 and 22, and was successful, it might also be used to help with fire prevention, Topfer said.</p><p> The coordinated approach would have three priorities: halting the spread of the fires, fighting them and preventing their recurrence.</p><p> While working in conjunction with national efforts, the UNEP would seek enforcement of the law which bans lighting fires for land-clearing purposes.</p><p>Indonesian Environment Minister Juwono Sudarsono said 65 per cent of the land burned in the current spate of fires in East Kalimantan was on land held by timber companies which had intentionally lit fires as a cheap but illegal method of land clearing prior to planting oil palms or other crops.</p><p>Indonesian authorities last year regularly blamed plantation owners for the fires, even announcing the number of companies they believed responsible, but no legal proceedings have been concluded against them.</p><p> Many nations, including Australia, and international agencies have been involved in firefighting efforts in Indonesia but the fires have continued to burn.</p><p> Topfer said he did not believe putting out the fires was an impossible task and that it was no good sitting back in an armchair waiting for the rains to come.</p><p> "We are not blue-eyed optimists; we are very realistic," he said.</p><p> (AAP)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-02-28</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="543"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:7VH0-C6H1-2RG6-Y549-00000-00Bushfire Royal Commission underway2009-04-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisPM6:22 PM AESTABCRachael BrownBushfire Royal Commission underway

LISA MILLAR: The Royal Commission into Victoria's devastating February bushfires has heard the state didn't realise it was dealing with 'a fire that could not be fought'.

The Black Saturday bushfires claimed 173 lives and destroyed more than 2,000 homes.

The counsel assisting the commission Jack Rush QC said the magnitude of the fire threat may not have been adequately conveyed.

The commission will review the state's fire warning and management systems, and began today by deciding which people and organizations would be allowed to give evidence.

Rachael Brown reports.

RACHAEL BROWN: The commission has heard all the signs of an impending bushfire disaster were there - a decade of drought, lowest January rainfall on record, 40 degree temperatures and 100 kilometre an hour wind gusts.

But counsel assisting the commission Jack Rush QC said only hindsight could ram home just what communities were gambling with.

JACK RUSH: Whilst people knew the 7th of February would be a day of extreme risk, they did not have the understanding that the risk, as the McArthur Forest Fire Index demonstrated, carried with it the potential of a fire that could not be fought.

RACHAEL BROWN: Mr Rush QC says a fire index of 50 is considered extreme. On Black Saturday the index was three times that amount but Victoria was blind to the implications.

JACK RUSH: The intensity of the potential fires would be such that it could not be imagined by our generation.

Not only the intensity of the fire, the heat of the fire, but its speed was phenomenal.

Fire spotted kilometres ahead, fireballs seemingly of atomic force came before the fire. The fire did not discriminate between buildings of brick, timber or other construction.

Such fires create their own weather and are beyond the most sophisticated attempts to control them.

The evidence will demonstrate people made decisions in relation to stay or go with an unrealistic optimism.

RACHAEL BROWN: Victoria's 'stay or go' policy will be the focus of the first block of hearings, which start next month.

Mr Rush QC said the Commission might find that, in some communities, 'stay' should never have been an option and that perhaps Victoria should devise evacuation policies like some parts of Europe and the US.

Just who warns those in the path of bushfires, and how the warning is conveyed, will be another focus.

It will be a very public affair, with cameras allowed to film proceedings. And a mammoth task for the commissioners, who've restricted oral submissions to those whose conduct will come under scrutiny.

Former Federal Court judge Bernard Teague, who's chairing the commission, explains the deadline pressures.

BERNARD TEAGUE: For an interim report it is 17th of August 2009, for our final report it is the 31st of July 2010. We plan to meet those deadlines. We can only do so by limiting the issues that we address and by dealing with the more critical issues first.

Many applicants have not been granted leave. If you are one of those we encourage you to focus in the short term on providing a detailed written submission.

There are other ways of permitting you to air facts and voice opinions than by having a formal right to appear at hearings.

RACHAEL BROWN: But many feel it's a slap in the face for bushfire survivors.

While their voices were heard at the 26 community consultations that have been held around the state, this did not count as formal evidence.

Mat Tinkler represents 30 individuals and groups who've all been denied leave to appear at the commission.

MAT TINKLER: We've assisted people who've lost family members; we've assisted people who were first on the scene at certain fire sites and providing emergency medical assistance; groups of people involved in the emergency response who might not necessarily agree with the views being put forward by the other bodies; people with expertise in relation to fire management, so a variety of views.

RACHAEL BROWN: Barrister Tim Tobin QC hopes to appear for those affected by fires thought to have been started by fallen or faulty power lines.

TIM TOBIN: We know that Coleraine and Horsham fires were fires where a conductor came off poles. The Weerite/Pomborneit fire was a fire were conductors clashed. The Mudgegonga fire, the Myrtleford fire was a fire where there was an insulator failure and wires clashing. The Kinglake was a failure of a conductor over a span of 1.125km.

RACHAEL BROWN: This issue's inclusion may be tricky, given the pending class action against SP AusNet over the allegation that one of its lines snapped, causing the Kilmore East blaze.

But Mr Tobin QC says it's important the commission considers the causes behind the fires, not just future warning systems.

TIM TOBIN: Because the major fires that have occurred over the last 35 years in Victoria, with life and asset destruction on private land, have been fires where they have had an involvement of power assets. And if you know how the fires are started, you then know how to prevent the fires from starting and make recommendations

RACHAEL BROWN: The commission will reconvene on the 11th of May.

LISA MILLAR: That report by Rachael Brown.
