urn:contentItem:4P89-SBM0-TXN5-V34M-00000-00Wildfires again cast pall over Indonesia1998-03-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 28Wildfires again cast pall over Indonesia

BALIKPAPAN, Indonesia.- Five men, some with shoes, others barefoot, trudged up the smoky forest highway toward a wall of flames.

"We're here to put out the fire. The authorities gave us these," one said, proudly referring to a battered plastic water tank strapped to his back.

Until now, he explained, they had to beat flames out with tree branches.

This time, they walked about 3km from the nearest water hole to fill each 15-litre tank.

When they finish dousing this fire, they will walk back, refill and hike to another blaze, he said.

Wildfires that poured choking smoke across much of South-East Asia and threatened the health of an estimated 70 million people last year have returned to the jungles of Borneo island.

Indonesia's worried neighbours have demanded strong action. But bogged down in its worst economic crisis in three decades, Indonesia admits that without heavy rain it has almost no chance of preventing haze from spreading across the region again.

Most days, a heavy haze blankets the cities of Balikpapan and Samarinda, both about 1200km north of Jakarta. Here the sun burns orange in a grey sky. Smoke fills the nose, irritates the throat and stings the eyes. Doctors warn of a dramatic increase in respiratory infections and asthma if the haze persists.

"We could face major health problems if it does not rain soon," said Dr Jusuf, the head of a hospital in Samarinda. The smoke is worst in two national parks that are home to rare species such as orangutan apes.

Scientists warn that together with drought, the haze could devastate harvests as it did last year when crops could not get enough sunshine to grow.

"The smoke has ruined my crop. Fruit from my trees is too small to sell," complains Kondo, a farmer who lives on the edge of the burning forest.

As last year, officials have said many of the fires appear to have been set, a cheap way to clear land.

Officials using satellite imaging count between 400 and 600 hotspots a day in eastern Borneo and dozens more in central Sumatra island. Fires have also been spotted in the Malaysian-controlled northern part of Borneo.

At this time of year, these locales should be green, lush and wet. But meteorologists say El Nino has cut short the rainy season, leaving jungles, farmland and commercial forest areas tinder-dry.

The government says about 8900ha of land have been blackened in Borneo. But Grant Beebe, a forest fire expert from Boise, Idaho, said the damage could be in the hundreds of thousands of hectares.

Several hundred soldiers, firefighters and farmers are battling the fires with buckets or branches of trees, said Mr Beebe, who works for a German-funded aid project monitoring the problem.

They haven't had much success, he said, but "it's an improvement on the past when people just let fires burn. At least now they know they should at least try to control them."

When the fires first started in Borneo costly water bombing planes were sent up for a few days - to little effect.

The government then began an operation in which a plane drops salt crystals into clouds to induce rain. But so far that also has failed.

Illus: Villagers used branches against fires on Balikpapan, Borneo, last year. The problem remains, the methods are little improved.

urn:contentItem:7VH0-6VW0-YB64-40BN-00000-00Bushfire commission to examine mass evacuations2009-04-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Bushfire commission to examine mass evacuationsTHE ROYAL COMMISSIONKAREN KISSANE

MASS evacuations of people in fire-prone regions might have to be considered on future days of extreme danger to try to avoid another Black Saturday, the royal commission on the disaster has been told.

On its opening in Melbourne yesterday, the commission heard that people who stayed to defend their homes on February 7 were "entirely unaware" of the severity of what they faced.

Fireballs "seemingly of atomic force" created their own weather and were beyond the most sophisticated attempts to control them, said Jack Rush, QC, counsel assisting the commission, in his opening remarks.

Australia's "stay or go" policy, allowing people in fire-prone areas to make their own decisions on what to do on days of extreme danger, was unique and would be a key focus of the commission, Mr Rush signalled.

He compared the experience of Victoria with that of the United States and parts of Europe, where evacuation is seen as the safest approach during periods of high fire danger. In the 2007 California fires, which destroyed 3069 houses, nearly 1 million residents were evacuated from 350,000 homes, and only 10 people died, he said. In the Victorian fires,more than 2000 homes were destroyed and 173 people died.

The commission would examine whether an evacuation policy would be suitable in some places on extreme days," Mr Rush said.

"Some particular areas of this state, as a consequence of habitat and topography ... are indefensible from a fire-fighting point of view," he said.

Mr Rush also said evidence would be presented demonstrating that on February 7 many people remained in their homes unaware of approaching fires until it was too late.

He said official "leaving early" advice from authorities suggested that residents make a decision by 10am. But by 10am and even by midday on February 7, there was little fire activity in Victoria.

"There was no reported fire in Kilmore East, Horsham, Kinglake, Marysville, Strathewen, Callignee, Bendigo or Coleraine," he said. "Why would a resident of any of the fire-affected regions implement the 'Go' part of the policy if they were not aware of any fire threat?"

Mr Rush also said that while Victorians knew in advance that February 7 was a day of extreme risk, they did not understand there was a chance of "a fire that could not be fought".

He said a rating of 12 to 25 on the McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index was considered high and a rating over 50 extreme. "The index on 7 February reached previously unrecorded levels ranging from 120 to 180.

The blazes probably reached an intensity of 100,000 kilowatts per square metre. "The maximum intensity for control of forest fires is about 4000 kilowatts per metre," he said.

Mr Rush said the commission would hear evidence that communications failed to cope on February 7 and warnings fell behind the advancing fires and the way they developed after a wind change.

He said the commission would scrutinise the websites of fire-fighting organisations and assess "the ability to track fires at all". Warnings needed to be accurate and timely, he said.

"Underpinning such warnings is the ability for agencies to rapidly analyse on-the-ground intelligence, to monitor risks as they emerge and develop, predict future impacts and point to the best course of action."

Mr Rush said emergency refuges had been set up after the 1983 Ash Wednesday fires and were maintained by local councils during the 1980s but over time had been decommissioned. "Questions as to uniform standards, the legal liability of local councils who maintained them and the risk people may drive to refuges in dangerous circumstances have been raised as reasons for decommissioning," he said.

Mr Rush said a new national building standard, adopted soon after February 7, failed to cover important questions for fire-prone areas. The commission would look at issues including building maintenance, exit before and after fires, bunkers, water and power.

He said some houses built to the highest standards had burned to the ground, so the inquiry had commissioned analysis on a street-by-street basis to help make findings about building codes.

Mr Rush also raised concerns surrounding fuel reduction, saying it was constrained by complex rules.

"Many municipalities in high-risk bushfire areas have a land management overlay, an environmental significance overlay, a vegetation protection overlay, a wildfire management overlay," he said. "On their face, the planning provisions appear complex and bureaucratic."

Due to time constraints, the commission's eight-week block of hearings beginning on May 11 will examine only warnings and the stay-or-go policy.

Commission chairman Bernard Teague said the inquiry could meet its deadlines only if it limited the issues it addressed and looked at the more critical issues first, with a focus on saving lives.

Mr Rush said remaining questions, including causes of the fires, would be addressed after the interim report was delivered in August. Discussion papers would be published on some topics.

The interim report might have suggestions about the stay-or-go policy but would not have a recommendation about whether the scheme should be replaced, Mr Rush said. The final report is due in July 2010.

The commission's hearings will be streamed on the internet.

urn:contentItem:5HSW-8F01-JD67-1399-00000-00Bushfire review to assess evacuation2009-04-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:19ZLexisNexisAGRIBUSINESSBushfire review to assess evacuationSKAREN KISSANE

MASS evacuations of people in bushfire-prone areas might have to be considered on future days of extreme danger to try to avoid another Black Saturday, the royal commission on the disaster has been told.

On its opening in Melbourne yesterday, the commission heard that people who stayed to defend their homes on February 7 were "entirely unaware" of the severity of what they faced.

"Fireballs seemingly of atomic force came before the fire," said Jack Rush, QC, counsel assisting the commission, in opening remarks. "Such fires create their own weather and are beyond the most sophisticated attempts to control them."

Australia's "stay or go" policy, allowing people to make their own decisions on days of extreme danger, was unique and would be a key focus of the commission, Mr Rush signalled.

He compared the experience of Victoria with that of the United States, where evacuation is seen as the safest approach at times of high danger.

In the 2007 California fires, which destroyed 3069 houses, nearly 1 million residents were evacuated from 350,000 homes, and only 10 people died, he said. In Victoria on February 7, more than 2000 homes were destroyed and 173 people died.

The commission of inquiry into what Mr Rush called the nation's "greatest peacetime disaster" would examine whether an evacuation policy would be suitable in some places on extreme days, he said.

"Some particular areas of this state, as a consequence of habitat and topography ' are indefensible from a fire-fighting point of view," he said.

Mr Rush said evidence would be presented demonstrating that on February 7 many people remained in their homes unaware of approaching fires until it was too late. He said the official "leaving early" advice from authorities suggested that residents make a decision on whether to stay or leave by 10am on an extreme fire danger day.

But by 10am and even midday on February 7, there was little fire activity in Victoria.

"There was no reported fire in Kilmore East, Horsham, Kinglake, Marysville, Strathewen, Callignee, Bendigo or Coleraine," he said.

"Why would a resident of any of the fire-affected regions implement the 'Go' part of the policy if they were not aware of any fire threat?"

Mr Rush also said that while Victorians knew in advance that February 7 was a day of extreme risk, they did not understand there was a chance of "a fire that could not be fought".

He said a rating of 12 to 25 on the McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index was considered high and a rating over 50 extreme. "The index on 7 February reached previously unrecorded levels ranging from 120 to 180."

The blazes probably reached an intensity of 100,000 kilowatts per square metre. "The maximum intensity for control of forest fires is about 4000 kilowatts per metre," Mr Rush said.

He said the commission would hear evidence that communications failed to cope on February 7, with warnings falling behind the advancing fires and the way they developed after a wind change.

He said the commission would scrutinise the websites of fire-fighting organisations and assess "the ability to track fires at all". Warnings needed to be accurate and timely, he said. "Underpinning such warnings is the ability for agencies to rapidly analyse on-the-ground intelligence, to monitor risks as they emerge and develop, predict future impacts and point to the best course of action."

Another issue raised by Mr Rush yesterday was the decommissioning over time of emergency refuges set up after the 1983 Ash Wednesday fires.

"Questions as to uniform standards, the legal liability of local councils who maintained them and the risk people may drive to refuges in dangerous circumstances have been raised as reasons for decommissioning," he said.

Mr Rush said a new national building standard, adopted soon after February 7, failed to cover important questions for fire-prone areas. The commission would look at issues including building maintenance, exit before and after fires, bunkers, water and power.

He said some houses built to the highest standards had burned to the ground, so the inquiry had commissioned analysis on a street-by-street basis to help make findings about building codes.

Mr Rush also raised concerns surrounding fuel reduction, saying it was constrained by complex rules. "Many municipalities in high-risk bushfire areas have a land management overlay, an environmental significance overlay, a vegetation protection overlay, a wildfire management overlay," he said. "On their face, the planning provisions appear complex and bureaucratic."

Due to time constraints, the commission's eight-week block of hearings beginning on May 11 will examine only warnings and the stay-or-go policy.

Commission chairman Bernard Teague said the inquiry could meet its deadlines only if it limited the issues it addressed and looked at the more critical issues first, with a focus on saving lives.

Mr Rush said remaining questions, including causes of the fires, would be addressed after the interim report was delivered in August. Discussion papers would be published on some topics.

The interim report might have suggestions about the stay-or-go policy but would not have a recommendation about whether the scheme should be replaced, Mr Rush said. The final report is due in July 2010.

The commission's hearings will be streamed on the internet.

MASS evacuations of people in bushfire-prone areas might have to be considered on future days of extreme danger to try to avoid another Black Saturday, the royal commission on the disaster has been told.

On its opening in Melbourne yesterday, the commission heard that people who stayed to defend their homes on February 7 were "entirely unaware" of the severity of what they faced.

"Fireballs seemingly of atomic force came before the fire," said Jack Rush, QC, counsel assisting the commission, in opening remarks. "Such fires create their own weather and are beyond the most sophisticated attempts to control them."

Australia's "stay or go" policy, allowing people to make their own decisions on days of extreme danger, was unique and would be a key focus of the commission, Mr Rush signalled.

He compared the experience of Victoria with that of the United States, where evacuation is seen as the safest approach at times of high danger.

In the 2007 California fires, which destroyed 3069 houses, nearly 1 million residents were evacuated from 350,000 homes, and only 10 people died, he said. In Victoria on February 7, more than 2000 homes were destroyed and 173 people died.

The commission of inquiry into what Mr Rush called the nation's "greatest peacetime disaster" would examine whether an evacuation policy would be suitable in some places on extreme days, he said.

"Some particular areas of this state, as a consequence of habitat and topography ... are indefensible from a fire-fighting point of view," he said.

Mr Rush said evidence would be presented demonstrating that on February 7 many people remained in their homes unaware of approaching fires until it was too late. He said the official "leaving early" advice from authorities suggested that residents make a decision on whether to stay or leave by 10am on an extreme fire danger day.

"Underpinning such warnings is the ability for agencies to rapidly analyse on-the-ground intelligence, to monitor risks as they emerge and develop, predict future impacts and point to the best course of action."

KUALA LUMPUR: The Cabinet has ordered that all express and tour buses be installed with speed limiting devices, known as black boxes, with immediate effect in a move to further protect road users.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> 2. BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN: Prime Minister Dr Mahathir Mohamad and Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah Mu'izzaddin Waddaulah of Brunei last night discussed the current economic situation in South-East Asia during his one-day visit to the oil-rich country.</p><p>3. KUALA LUMPUR: Special squads to detect bush fires may be set up at all local authorities in a bid to check their spread.</p><p> SUN</p><p> 1. KUALA LUMPUR: Malaysia and Thailand will develop their common areas und the Indonesia-Malaysia-Thailand Growth Triangle (IMT-GT) at a "realistic" pace in the wake of the regional economic slowdown.</p><p> 2. KUALA LUMPUR: Malaysia has welcomed the pending visit of UN secretary-general Kofi Annan to Baghdad this weekend and reiterated that diplomacy is the only realistic option.</p><p> 3. KUALA LUMPUR: Monash University officials have expressed confidence in setting up a branch campus in Malaysia.</p><p> BERITA HARIAN</p><p> 1. SEPANG: The KL International Airport (KLIA), which is almost completed, will not exceed its estimated cost of between RM8 bil and RM9 bil despite the economic downturn, KL International Airport Bhd (KLIAB) chairman Clifford Herbert said yesterday.</p><p> 2. JOHOR BARU: Foreigners wishing to marry locals must get written permission from their respective embassies to avoid immigration and religious-related problems.</p><p> NEW STRAITS TIMES</p><p> 1. KUALA LUMPUR: As thick smoke from forest fire within Sarawak reached a hazardous level in Miri, the government sounded an early warning of the return of the haze.</p><p> 2. KUALA LUMPUR: The cabinet has agreed to review the penalties for reckless drivers. The tougher penalties are likely to include a mandatory jail term.</p><p> 3. KUALA LUMPUR: Thailand wants all development projects under the Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand Growth Triangle (IMTGT) agreement to be approached with caution in view of the economic downturn.</p><p> UTUSAN MALAYSIA</p><p> 1. KUALA LUMPUR: Concerned over the increasing number of deaths in road accidents, the Cabinet has directed the Transport Ministry to review the punishment against reckless drivers, including the introduction of a mandatory jail sentence.</p><p> 2. KOTA KINABALU: A government officer in Sabah was commended by the Anti-Corruption Agency for turning down a RM100,000 bribe last year.</p><p> 3. KUALA LUMPUR: Subscribers and a telephone company in the country lost about RM85.212 million last year due to telecommunications line theft.</p><p> NANYANG SIANGPAU</p><p> 1. KUALA LUMPUR: The Securities Commission has imposed a RM100,000 fine on United Engineers Malaysia Bhd. in connection with the date of its acquiring of Renong equity shares. It says UEM has faltered section 341 of the listing regulations.</p><p> 2. KUALA LUMPUR: Housing developers have been advised to lodge report with Housing and Local Government Ministry if certificates of fitness for their completed houses have been withheld by local authorities. It is unfair to house buyers if local authorities try to withhold CFs on technical ground.</p><p> 3. KLANG: The Klang Valley will face shortage of drinking water in two to three years time. About 40 percent of water wasted is caused by burst pipes.</p><p> (Bernama)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3S25-D1D0-0048-T50N-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="584"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:49NR-WV20-01S8-B3JW-00000-00<published>1995-07-24T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:20Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>15 dead on 'baked' Continent</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>MICHAEL THURSTON</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">PARIS: Temperatures soared to baking point across Europe yesterday, killing at least 15 people. Locals watch a huge forest fire raging out of control on the outskirts of Athens The mercury rose to 40 degrees just as Europe hits the beaches for the long summer break.Record temperatures were recorded in Paris, where pollution also soared to alert levels, sparking warnings of a car ban.The heat in southern Spain has killed at least 12 people in the past week, most elderly.Temperatures have hovered above 40 degrees and reached 50 at times in the cities of Seville and Cordoba.Another 32 people were taken to hospital in the southern region of Andalusia.Three deaths were reported in France, all from heart attacks apparently brought on by searing temperatures.On the Mediterranean island of Corsica, a 27-year-old man had a heart attack while out walking, while a 67-yearold woman died of a heatinduced heart attack on on the Atlantic coast near La Rochelle, police said.Later in the day, a 58-year-old hiker died while out walking with his family in the Pyrenees. Rescuers tried to resuscitate him after he collapsed at 2,200 metres, but he suffered a heart attack through lack of oxygen and overheating.In other countries, employees were sent home because of the heat.In Greece, the traditional summer swelter in Athens has been somewhat alleviated by a ban on traffic in the city, but forest fires have hit a number of islands and areas around the capital.</p><p>In Italy, no specific heat-related deaths have been recorded, but authorities in Rome and Milan have joined cities like Paris in appealing to motorists to leave their cars at home to cut choking fumes in city centres.Further north, the French deaths sparked health fears in countries not used to such extremes of temperature.In Germany, not known for extremes of temperature, the mercury was expected to reach 37 today and at least one major office workers' union called on its members to go home if temperatures rose above 31 degrees.In Paris, pollution levels soared to alert level two - on a scale of three - for the second time in a month, sparking a renewed warning that car restrictions could be introduced. Mayor Jean Tiberi said public information campaigns might not be enough."If all those methods are not enough, I would not hesitate to call on the authorities to take measures to restrict traffic," he warned.Temperatures, meanwhile, soared to a record 36.2 degrees during the day, equivalent to levels recorded during the drought summer of 1976, authorities said.The heat wave was not all bad news.In Britain, temperatures 10 degrees above the seasonal average sparked unusual sights for visitors to the Kew Botanical Gardens.Keepers said an eightyear-old bread plant bore fruit for the first time, while a rare blossom from Niger came into flower for 30 minutes in response to the unaccustomed heat.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5CHS-5261-JD3N-52NG-00000-00Star quality in La Gomera2014-06-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisTRAVELPg. 6Star quality in La GomeraLINDA COOKSON

One of the smallest of Spain's Canary Islands is the unlikely setting for a Hollywood blockbuster

LIGHTS, camera, action! The small fishing port of Playa de Santiago, on the southern tip of the Canary Island of La Gomera, has never known such excitement. Chosen as a key shooting location for Ron Howard's forthcoming film In the Heart of the Sea (due for release next year), its quayside is abuzz with trailers and catering vans.

Burly cameramen are lugging equipment on to speed boats. Runners with clipboards are rounding up a busload of enthusiastic extras for costume fittings. And a cluster of schoolgirls are star-spotting like mad, as Hollywood's finest, clad in 19th-century sailors' gear, make their way towards the banana-yellow shuttle boat that will whisk them out to film at sea.

Based on the same true story that inspired Herman Melville's Moby-Dick, Nathaniel Philbrick's award-winning novel In the Heart of the Sea (published in 2000) -recounts the tragedy of the whaling ship Essex, sunk by a sperm whale in the middle of the Pacific Ocean. A fantastic black-rigged replica of the ill-fated vessel (built in -England) bobs incongruously on the calm horizon, its masts bathed in a golden wash of Canarian sunshine.

At first sight, pint-sized La Gomera - sitting prettily in an island chain renowned for its equable climate - might seem a strange location to have settled on for a tale built around tempest-lashed heroics. Deadly waves are in short supply. The filmmakers had to construct a special infinity pool by the former tomato packaging warehouse on Tapahuga Beach to simulate the full-on -storm scenes.

But Howard and his scouts definitely knew what they were doing. As the second smallest of the Canary Islands, a one-hour ferry-ride from Tenerife and with no international airport, La Gomera is a world apart from the mass-tourism of its larger neighbours. With only a handful of low-key resorts, there was never going to be much risk of the Essex's hapless crew fetching up on a jarring parade of neon-signed shops peddling water-wings or advertising jet-skis for hire.

Instead, the island's starkly rugged coastline of awesome volcanic cliffs rippling down to the water's edge in stiff rocky folds, feels almost eerily enduring - and -(crucially for the film, of course) totally undateable. -Inland, the mountainous centre is cloaked in a dense, misty rainforest of ancient trees hung, Druid-like, with beards of moss and lichen. It's as timeless and unspoilt as you could hope for.

As a place to visit in springtime, La Gomera is a total delight. The tangled green groves of the rainforest are rippled with carpets of brilliant pink bicacaros, Canarian bell flowers. Mountain villages float in drifts of white broom and almond blossom. On the coast, fringed with date palms and banana trees, the sea sparkles peacefully in temperatures that seldom vary from around 20C. Don't expect the blazing heat or golden sands of Caribbean beaches. Most beaches are rocky. (There may even be a little rain.) But if you're searching for sun and serenity in a gentle, unspoilt island retreat steeped in tradition, look no further. And you can certainly be confident of a genuinely warm welcome from La Gomera's friendly locals, keen to share their homeland's special character with visitors. With the island still very much a novice in the tourism stakes, the whole ambience is refreshingly uncynical.

Such tourism as there is can be found mainly on the west coast. Valle Gran Rey has a stunning sprawl of wild and rocky black-sand beaches, backed by majestic ravines (Valle Gran Rey means "Valley of the Kings"). Otherwise, most visitors-in-the-know head south for -unpretentious Playa de Santiago, a friendly working fishing settlement with an endearingly scruffy town beach. This is La Gomera's sunniest spot and it's where I choose to stay (along, as it turns out, with the director and most of the cast and crew of In the Heart of the Sea).

We certainly aren't roughing it. The four-star Hotel Jardin Tecina, set on a clifftop above the town, is laid out like a traditional Canarian village in exuberant, flower-filled gardens. There are palm-fringed bars and terraces, and attentive waiters galore - giving plenty of scope for your own brand of silver-screen decadence as you lounge like a diva by the poolside. It's also a wonderfully tranquil spot. The vistas from the sea-view rooms are spectacular. You can while away hours on your balcony watching the colours of the water change from turquoise to indigo to lilac, like a roll of shot silk, as butterflies and exotic birds flit all around you.

On day four of my stay, I wander down towards the town and discover that my friendly local beach bar - the ramshackle La Chalana - has undergone a dramatic change of location. Its wonky tables and cane chairs are now spilling haphazardly on to the edge of an early 19th-century Polynesian village. A nearby stretch of banana plantation had been cleared for carpentry and set-building, and crew-members with blowtorches are busily distressing a fleet of rustic-looking canoes carved from hollowed-out tree-trunks. A mixture of real palm trees and bright green fakes have sprung up on the beach. Tangled branches and planks of driftwood have been choreographed artfully into a photogenic array of native huts. And a derelict warehouse has been transformed into a small chapel. A set dresser perches on a ladder with what looks like a huge brass church bell clutched in her free hand. It is obviously as light as a feather.

La Chalana's affable host, Eric - who, with his curly black hair and earring, looks rather like a film star himself - is having the time of his life serving up tapas and beer by the trayful. He is sure he recognises some of the transplanted palm trees, he tells me. They come from the schoolyard in San Sebastian, La Gomera's capital. He -remembers sitting under them at break-times to smoke illicit cigarettes.

Eric is not alone in his enthusiasm. Everyone I speak to is thrilled by the filming - not least since the star, Australian Chris Hemsworth, is married to Elsa Pataky, a popular Spanish actress who has accompanied him for the shoot. More pragmatically, In the Heart of the Sea brings a crucial source of additional revenue to enable the island to address the environmental damage caused by a disastrous forest fire in 2012 - as well as much-needed employment for locals, who are mucking in happily as caterers, security guards and prop-makers.

La Gomera is also looking to the future. Although the island has been recognised for some time as a paradise for walkers, its more mainstream attractions - uncommercialised beaches and picture-postcard mountain villages - have remained a well-kept secret. There's real excitement now among Gomeros that this major, -potentially worldwide, exposure will encourage new visitors to fall for their island's sleepy charms and living history. (After all, as everyone is keen to remind me, San Sebastian was the starting point for Christopher -Columbus's epic 1492 Atlantic crossing. And where else in the world will you find "El Silbo", an indigenous whistling language developed so that farmers could communicate with each other across jaw-droppingly steep terraces?) Towards the end of my visit, inspired by the filming, I decide to embrace the whale theme in earnest. I book a trip on board Jose Miguel's excursion boat Tina and take to the water. I am rewarded with an entrancing marine ballet, courtesy of a pod of pilot whales and an especially obliging school of dolphins who flip and dip in glorious silver arcs as they ride in and out of the bow wave from our boat as it heads out to sea.

I look back at the bulking headlands of La Gomera's proud cliffs, veined with blood-red bands of sandstone, and then ahead to the horizon, where the doughty ship Essex has magically split in two, while cameramen scud around in dinghies, capturing the moment of its doom.

I really am in the heart of the sea, I realise. And lovely La Gomera is well on its way to becoming a film star in its own right. Don't wait for the movie - go now.

urn:contentItem:4P7G-YHW0-TXN5-R2G6-00000-00BUSHFIRE SMOKE MAY DUMP CAR EXHAUST POLLUTION OVER CITY1987-10-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 4BUSHFIRE SMOKE MAY DUMP CAR EXHAUST POLLUTION OVER CITYBOB BEALE, Science Reporter

Sydneysiders may be getting an extra dose of hazardous air pollution from car exhausts this summer - in the smoke from bushfires.

That surprising possibility has been raised by the first unexpected results of a big experimental forest fire near the US city of Los Angeles.

The fire was lit as part of the first detailed field study of the nuclear winter theory, but smoke samples taken from it have raised new questions about a quite different airborne hazard in the smog-shrouded city.

The Los Angeles fire smoke was found to contain enormous amounts of pollutants that could only have come from car exhausts, according to the US science magazine Discover.

When compared with samples taken from forest fires in remote areas of North America, the Los Angeles smoke had concentrations of some sulphur and nitrogen compounds that were up to 100 times greater.

The smoke also contained up to four times as much of the toxic heavy metal lead. Some of the nitrogen and sulphur compounds are key components of smog, and can form acids that make up acid rain.

Dr Lawrence Radke, an atmospheric scientist at the University of Washington, says the source of the noxious compounds was motor vehicle exhausts emitted over decades.

The exhausts had drifted from nearby freeways to settle on plants and soil, then were liberated by the fire.

Environmental scientists in Sydney agree that the city has the basic elements necessary to be a candidate for a similar problem: 1.5 million cars, an encircling swath of forests, and regular summer bushfires.

Mr Len Ferrari, a principal air scientist with the State Pollution Control Commission, said yesterday that Los Angeles had worse air pollution and more sulphurous fuel than that used in Sydney.

But he conceded, along with Dr Frank Cattel, an environmental chemist at Macquarie University's centre for environmental and urban studies, that the Los Angeles finding could be quite relevant to Sydney.

"I would expect similar but more muted effects here, and it's something well worth looking at," Dr Cattell said yesterday.

Dr Cattell's research group has recently identified another serious health hazard from bushfire smoke, in the form of polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).

Those complex organic compounds result from incomplete combustion, and several have been shown to cause cancer.

Dr Cattel calculates that airborne PAHs released by car exhausts, bushfires, and backyard incinerators are probably responsible for about 30 of the 1,000 lung cancer deaths each year in Sydney.

New pollution control equipment on cars and bans on backyard burning would help to control the PAH problem, he said.

urn:contentItem:4P85-12R0-TXN5-R253-00000-00Warning of unrest as poor pay for IMF bailout1997-10-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESInternational NewsPg. 11Warning of unrest as poor pay for IMF bailout* INDONESIALOUISE WILLIAMS Herald Correspondent in Jakarta

Rising prices, cutbacks in health services and lay-offs resulting from economic reforms to be pushed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) will hit Indonesia's poor and could fuel social unrest, a group of non-government organisations said yesterday.

The WAHLI coalition of environmental and grassroots organisations said measures sought by the IMF in exchange for a program to rescue Indonesia's corporate sector from the currency crisis were expected to be severe.

"Fuel subsidies will be stopped, government expenditure reduced - we are afraid the spending on hospitals, local clinics and schools will be cut back," WAHLI's executive director, Ms Emmy Hafild, said.

The expected increase in fuel prices would affect transport costs and push up the price of all basic commodities, she said. The downturn in the labour-intensive construction industry would force lay-offs and further labour unrest should be expected.

"Those who will sacrifice the most will be the poorest. But the business groups with vested interests will continue to receive special rights to exploit the nation's national resources," Ms Hafild said of Indonesia's dominant corporate sector, with its powerful political connections.

WAHLI said it feared increasing violence in Indonesian society as the stresses of vast forest fires and the severe drought, combined with spending cutbacks, began to affect ordinary people, already suffering under unemployment rates of 38 per cent.

"What we are worried about is that the usual climax of fires and long periods of drought is famine and crop failures. There could be a long period of unrest."

The IMF, the World Bank and officials of the Soeharto Government continued closed- door meetings in Jakarta yesterday. The rupiah, pushed to an all-time low last week ahead of the call for IMF assistance, held on to modest gains, but remained well below its previous value.

WAHLI said its own investigation into the forest fires which continue to burn across parts of Indonesia showed that more than 1.1 million hectares of forest have been lost, compared with the 400,000 hectares conceded by the Government.

Environment Ministry officials warned on Monday that the haze and fire problem was not over, after the number of fires sharply increased as a very hot, dry and windy weather pattern settled across Indonesia.

WAHLI said the Government had instructed local newspaper editors to stop blaming big timber and plantation companies and to instead blame the El Nin~o pattern.

Ms Hafild said the group was not confident that threats against big companies which started the fires as a means of cheap and quick land clearing would be prosecuted, nor that any fundamental changes would be made to prevent a repeat of this year's environmental disaster.

She said about 97 per cent of Indonesia's wood product exports were produced using virgin rainforest and that renewable timber plantations had not yet matured.

"The haze and forest fire problem runs parallel to the financial crisis. The fundamentals of both are the distortion of the economy, monopolies and vested interests in the economy which have not been addressed."

urn:contentItem:7V31-V301-2RR2-D40F-00000-00A new front in fighting fires2009-02-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisCOMPUTERSNextPg. 7A new front in fighting firesCynthia Karena

Computer simulation has become an important tool for firefighters, writes Cynthia Karena

FIRE authorities at the Black Saturday bushfires in Gippsland were aided by a computer simulation model called Phoenix that predicts probable fire spread.

Phoenix enabled fire authorities to determine where a fire was likely to be so they could send resources there ahead of time.

"Phoenix also helps us to (determine) where best to send resources to minimise the effect of fire," says Phoenix project leader Kevin Tolhurst, who operated the model in the emergency co-ordination centre during the recent bushfires in Gippsland. He is also a fire behaviour specialist and a senior lecturer in fire ecology and management at the University of Melbourne.

"Using fuel (type), topography and weather conditions, we can look at the probability of a fire and its impact," Dr Tolhurst says. "We are able to look at a few scenarios. We can look ahead to see the consequences of actions.

"During the fires, I used the model to look at what would happen if the fire escaped from the control line - how far would it run? How could we fight the fire most effectively?

"For example, once we know the worst places the fire can escape from, we can use aircraft early on at these critical points."

Phoenix can also be used to see how different fire management strategies will affect houses and infrastructure.

Simulation graphics from Phoenix can't be published yet as it may cause difficulties with the Royal Commission and the coronial inquiries.

Input to Phoenix includes the starting point of the fire, fuel type, wind, weather, topography (height and slope of the ground), and the effect of recent fires on fuel levels.

Spotting information is also critical to the model. Spotting is when spot fires are started by embers blown ahead of the main fire.

"Spot fires can significantly increase the rate of spread of the main fire front across the landscape and enable the fire to cross barriers such as freeways and lakes," says Dr Tolhurst.

Phoenix models the occurrence and development of spot fires within about 10kilometres of the main fire front. It calculates the effect of the convective updraft caused by thousands of spot fires within 200metres of the fire front.

Weather information is also critical, says Dr Tolhurst.

"We need to know the wind direction and speed," he says. "But the weather conditions take the longest to input; it could take up to an hour to get the information. Rather than wait for the forecast, we are writing code to used gridded forecast weather, using a six-kilometre grid and generated every 12hours.

"This will reduce the time waiting for weather input and increase the spatial accuracy of the weather data."

Phoenix uses a single stream of weather conditions for wind speed and direction, but will add a model from the US (called Wind Ninja) that uses topography to determine local wind speed and directions so wind movement over hilly terrain can be extrapolated. For example, fire moves faster up a hill as there is a smaller area the higher up it advances.

"The thing that's special about Phoenix is that we include disruptions, such as roads or streams from a GIS (geographic information system)," Dr Tolhurst says. "We look at the fire characteristics and see if the fire can breach them or will be halted by them. We (also) incorporate the effect of fire suppression on fire spread in an interactive way. This is different to anything else in the world. We can then immediately deploy suppression action, that is, bulldozers, aircraft, water tankers.

"Given the suppression resources, are they able to suppress fire at that point? This is important, as suppression is always a part of the fire, and impacts on its spread."

Phoenix uses three main fire models - CSIRO's bushfire and grassland models, and McArthur's forest fire behaviour model - and has significantly improved on these, says Dr Tolhurst.

"For example, McArthur's model is used where there is one type of forest, and Phoenix accounts for different fuel type mixes," he says.

Phoenix was developed in Visual Basic (VB.NET) "because it allows developers to annotate the code comprehensively," says Dr Tolhurst.

"The US system runs on a mini-super-computer (16processors), but our plan is to get Phoenix on to a server so it can be accessed and run from one location."

Initially the Department of Sustainability and Environment's server will be used, then possibly the Geoscience Australia's server in Canberra.

Phoenix is not used in all fires as there are not enough skilled operators. In these cases a spreadsheet is used to run the models manually.

"We need to train more people," Dr Tolhurst says. "The results of the model are only as good as the operator, who needs experience and a depth of knowledge and understanding about the consequences of various inputs.

"We need more resources. There are only 1.1people working on this. The Bushfire CRC (Co-operative Research Centres) funds one programmer and I work on it as support from the University of Melbourne."

TWO PHOTOS: Fire specialist Kevin Tolhurst. A screen grab from Phoenix showing part of the Deans Marsh fire from Ash Wednesday.

urn:contentItem:4R6B-J1D0-TXN5-S0GD-00000-00Your week ahead2007-11-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 39Your week aheadwith Lilith

As today's windswept and interesting birthday person Billy Connolly notes: "There's no such thing as bad weather, only the wrong clothes." A sensible working metaphor for this week, when changing what you can makes what you can't change bearable ...

Sagittarius Nov 23-Dec21 The sun in your birthday month rockets you into full Sagittarian dynamo mode: provocative one minute, infuriating the next; offending some, delighting others, entertaining the rest. You so won't want to think before you act, but it's advised that before expressing personal opinions this week you consider how you'd want the same thing said to you.

Capricorn Dec 22-Jan 20 This whirlwind weekend could shake free some energetic density from any static attitudes, fixed opinions, rigid relationships or stitched up deals you might currently be engaged in. Liberating, eh? This week is a loose cannon - chaotic, all over the place, definitely needing the firm hand of Capricornian organisation, but fighting it all the way. Good luck.

Aquarius Jan 21-Feb 19 Freedom's your primary requirement this week. If you're finding your lifestyle limited or relationships rigid, don't forget you need the balance of both stability and room to move to be truly happy ... Avoid this week's overheated arguments and you'll enjoy its compensations: exciting conversation, inspiring ideas and quite a flirtatious buzz.

Pisces Feb 20- Mar 20 Getting involved in the quagmire of other people's problems will be very tiring this weekend, so do something positive for yourself instead, such as revising your outlook on obligations. You'll have enough to deal with this week getting your own philosophical and practical, logical and fanciful selves working together rather than against one another.

Aries Mar 21-Apr 20 Today's airy full moon is guaranteed to fan your flames, so aim for a controlled burn rather than the full forest-fire effect; be a lover, not a fighter, and spend the weekend with people you care about. This stimulating week will be an exhausting one as well if you don't spend at least some of it relaxing and indulging yourself and those around you.

Taurus Apr 21-May 21 Today's mutable full moon could loosen up Taurean habit patterns for a lively, energetic social weekend schmoozing with a much more vivid variety of people than usual - and drumming up some extra biz along the way. This week's refusal to play by the rules will test your improvisation skills, but it's good to be stretched; it prevents attitudinal arthritis.

Gemini May 22-Jun 21 This weekend's annual Gemini full moon shines on family, relatives and close friends who won't be holding back on discussing, disputing and debating all manner of provoking topics. Personal growth and creative endeavours are high priorities this week, so a strictly financial approach won't be anywhere near as attractive as an enhanced lifestyle package.

Cancer Jun 22-Jul 23 Full moon affects Cancerians more than any other sign. If this weekend brings strained relations with family or friends, the good news is it's all likely to change again almost instantly. If others are going on about wanting their space, don't even think of feeling rejected - it's just that time of year. Don't make a fuss and they'll get over it.

Leo Jul 24-Aug 23 Restraint is advised during the weekend full moon, majesties. Scattered concentration could cause accidents so don't speed, or do anything at all if you're worked up - except cool down. It's one thing to blaze your own trail and another to be out on your own. If independence is costing you closeness with others this week, perhaps it's getting too expensive?

Virgo Aug 24-Sep 23 This week's people will flagrantly and shamelessly flaunt all rules of etiquette and decorum over anything they feel strongly about, which is almost everything. They'll be shockingly outspoken then, just when you're about to lose it, and crack you up with something outrageously funny. This is a gift, so enjoy it while it's going.

Libra Sep 24-Oct 23 The moon's full, Venus is in Libra and this is the perfect weekend for a romantic getaway, far from full-moon madness, social frictions, family spats and domestic obligations. This week is likely to challenge certain beliefs you considered unchangeable, so in the midst of seasonal busyness keep your mind open for what could be quite life-altering ideas.

Scorpio Oct 24-Nov 22 If powerful emotions get in the way of seeing things objectively this week, taking a break is your most sensible survival strategy - somewhere or with someone who provides enough peace and tranquillity to debrief. Resist the impulse to lash out and say something you might regret. And if that's too hard an ask, don't be slow to say sorry.

DRAWING: By Rocco Fazzari

urn:contentItem:4P85-12R0-TXN5-R336-00000-00Parliament has become a pantomime1997-10-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESLettersPg. 14Parliament has become a pantomime

Is the House of Representatives a playhouse where the parliamentarians must perform ? Is the member holding the floor there to assassinate his opponents with grim, threatening mien, exaggerated gesticulation and a look of utter scorn at them as he departs, having triumphantly demolished the opposition to the applause of his cohorts?

Or is it a dignified House where the member adopts a civilised stance and rationally puts his argument, recognising that his opposite number may possibly have some merit in his point of view? Such a member would have my vote.

Albert Armstrong, October 4 Balgowlah.

Another night of mudslinging on the evening news. Accusation and counter accusation. Ranting, chortling and finger-pointing by comfortable men in grey suits.

Yet, this is Australia's national government where members dicker over $145 or $320 a night and a national government proposes a lower minimum wage as a way out of our economic woes.

Youth unemployment and youth suicide are pressing issues and our politicians are debating travel expenses. Indonesia burns, South-East Asia chokes in smog and the boys and girls on the hill in Canberra fire witty salvoes at each other over who is staying with his mum.

And they wonder why the masses out there are disenchanted.

Barry Holman, October 1 Vaucluse.

Perhaps Ted Mack could be persuaded to give a short course on ethics to both sides of the House during the 10 days this session should be extended to compensate the public for the time wasted while each side tried to prove the other the greater rorter.

James Reynolds, October 2 North Ryde.

How fortunate that the recent less than edifying goings-on in Canberra only resulted in anear tragedy. Perhaps the Federal Parliament should be re-named the National Perks and Wildlife.

M. Miles, October 4 Paddington.

After viewing the primary school performance of the Federal Parliament last week, I started to sing "Stop the world, I want to get off".

But when John Elliott and that maestro of wit, Malcolm Fraser, congratulated Peter Costello on his performance, I had to change to "Bring in clowns, don't worry they're here".

Margot McKenzie, October 7 Brighton-le-Sands.

The brouhaha of the travel expenses "debate" has reminded me of an allegory, viz:

A frog and a scorpion met on the bank of a river to escape a forest fire.

The scorpion asked the frog for a ride across on its back. The frog suggested that the scorpion would sting, but it replied that then both would drown. The frog agreed.

However, halfway across it felt a sting and cried "Why?'

The scorpion replied: "I couldn't help myself, it's part of my nature."

F. J. McGrath, October 2 East Lindfield.

I would like to thank the remaining members of the Federal Public Service for carrying on the business of our country during the past fortnight.

A pity there is no way of docking the pay of both Houses while politicians bickered, pausing only to annoy our global friends (if any) and hasten our older citizens into the gutter.

Richard Hoskins, October 6 Neutral Bay.

urn:contentItem:4P8H-NRF0-TXN5-S1HR-00000-00Indonesia apologises over fire haze1997-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 10Indonesia apologises over fire hazeLOUISE WILLIAMS

Pringluan, central Java, Tuesday

President Suharto has publicly apologised to Indonesia's neighbors over thousands of raging forest fires which have spread a thick smoke haze as far north as Kuala Lumpur, exposing tens of millions of people to dangerous levels of air pollution.

Indonesia declared a disaster on the two main islands of Kalimantan and Sumatra, where most of the fires are burning, and moved a regional environment meeting to Jakarta for urgent talks on the fire, pollution and the drought crisis gripping the region.

Mr Suharto issued the apology at the official opening of the Association of South-East Asian Nations environment ministers conference this morning, which was abruptly moved from the remote resort of Manado yesterday to allow Indonesian ministers to stay at their posts and handle the emergency.

Satellite images show more than 1000 fires burning in Indonesia's tropical forests, which have been badly damaged by logging and ravaged by a severe drought due to an El Nino weather pattern across Indonesia. Forest fires are an annual problem in Indonesia but the delay in the arrival of monsoon rains, and particularly hot daytime temperatures, has greatly exacerbated the haze problem.

The Government says at least 20 million Indonesians are being exposed daily to dangerous levels of air pollution and Reuter reported from Kuala Lumpur that children were being sent to school in smoke masks as pollution readings topped 300, on a scale

which sets 100 as a maximum safe reading.

Indonesia this morning opened a pollution phone line to give people the direction the fires were moving and visibility conditions. Operators said they were referring callers to health clinics for advice on respiratory problems, dizzyness and sore and itchy eyes associated with the smoke.

Many of the fires have been deliberately started as a cheap method of land clearing in rice fields and plantations in preparations for the monsoon season, which was due to begin around August but may be another two months away.

Indonesia has no adequate fire fighting equipment and traditionally relies on heavy tropical rain to extinguish the fires.

In opening the ASEAN conference Mr Suharto said: "To the communities of neighboring countries who have been disturbed by the fires in our territory, Indonesia offers its most sincere apologies."

The extent of the smoke haze and the severity of the drought has prompted the Suharto Government to take unprecedented action against logging companies, many of which are politically well connected.

Officials said 50 timber companies which are suspected of using fire to clear land had been given 15 days to prove their innocence or face the revoking of their timber permit.

The annual forest fire problem is closely to linked to rapid deforestation in Indonesia because land clearing allows sunlight to enter a tropical forest, encouraging the growth of flammable grasses and shrubs.

Two photos: Smoke alert: Schoolgirls in Malaysia's central Malacca state try to avoid inhaling smoky haze in the streets. The haze is being blamed on forest fires raging across Sumatra and Kalimantan in Indonesia, combined with the usual industrial pollution. Picture: Reuter; President Suharto, right, receives a letter about the fires from Malaysia's Environment Minister, Mr Law Hieng Ding. Picture: AP

urn:contentItem:4P85-12R0-TXN5-R2NR-00000-00Disappearing species begin to bite dust1997-10-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESInternational NewsPg. 22Disappearing species begin to bite dust* HAZE VICTIMS: ANIMALS, Dark days in IndonesiaLOUISE WILLIAMS

In a jungle clearing in drought-hit forests of western Borneo hundreds of endangered orang-utans are huddling, hungry and disoriented, forced out of the trees by the thick pall of smoke from fires raging nearby.

Unable to return to the forests, officials have no solution but to put them in cages and wait, the local villagers already fearful of raids on kitchen gardens by hungry jungle creatures displaced by the fires.

Wildlife experts say only 5,000 orang-utans remain in the Borneo forests, at least 500 have been displaced in the west and scores more are threatened in one of Indonesia's most important tracts of protected forest in Borneo's south.

The Indonesian Government has urged villagers living alongside the burning forests in Kalimantan, the Indonesian-controlled territory of Borneo and Sumatra, not to shoot the rare apes, tigers and elephants as they flee.

However, wildlife monitors in Jakarta have had reports of at least 10 female orang-utans being killed by villagers in south Kalimantan and their babies being seized for the illegal wildlife trade.

A researcher with the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) said: "We are working on this every day. It is certain there are many animals burned and there are many fleeing.

"Some people have already killed the orang-utans because they are large animals and they are perceived as a danger by villages. The orang-utans are fleeing the smoke, the fires and the drought."

At least 10 orphaned babies have been rescued by the WWF. It fears the killings of adults may lead to an increase in the illegal trade in babies of the species, which, with the Sumatran tiger and the elephant, is on a list of animals said to be on the brink of extinction.

Last week in Jambi, one of the worst-hit areas of Sumatra, where thick smoke has blocked out the sun for six weeks, a villager was killed and eaten by a tiger. It was the fifth fatal attack this month.

Only 500 Sumatran tigers are thought to now inhabit the shrinking forests of Sumatra. Elephants, too, are threatened by both the drought and the fires, their habitat reduced and food sources scarce, prompting raids on village gardens and retaliation by farmers.

Several stampedes by Sumatran elephants have been reported in recent weeks. One farmer has been killed and vast tracts of farmland destroyed.

Estimates of how much land has been damaged during the dry season's forest fire crisis range from 300,000 hectares (the Indonesian Government) to 800,000 hectares (the WWF).

Of more importance to Indonesia's threatened wildlife is what has happened to the country's protected forests, the last refuge from intensive forest clearing and plantation development.

The Forestry Ministry has estimated that 26,000 hectares of virgin, conservation forest have been lost. Under Indonesian land-use policies, large tracts of forests are allocated for clearing every year, forcing threatened species into smaller and smaller forests.

Government statistics show 7.3 million hectares of rainforest have been cleared since 1983, and clearing is averaging 500,000 hectares a year.

Indonesia's rarest animal is the rhinoceros, with only 47 remaining in Java and 250 in Sumatra.

Birds, too, have been hard hit by the shrinking forests and the commercial trade in rare species, with only 200 remaining maleos, a peacock-like bird, fewer than 200 rare starlings and about 500 Mollucan cockatoos.

urn:contentItem:53X9-M2N1-DYG0-91B6-00000-00FED:Drought, rain and now grass fire risk2011-09-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSFED:Drought, rain and now grass fire riskMegan NeilMELBOURNE Sept 30

  After the drought came the rain. And after that may well come the fires.
   Last summer's heavy rains have transformed large parts of the middle of Australia, with sparse desert replaced by waist - or even shoulder-high - grass in places.
   It may look spectacular, but it also means Australia faces the prospect of huge fires burning for months across its centre.


   Experts say the season could be a repeat of the summer of 1974-75, when fires throughout central Australia razed 117 million hectares - 15 per cent of the continent.
   Millions of hectares could burn, bushfire expert Phil Cheney says.
   All it takes is a lightning strike to set the grass alight, and once a wildfire takes hold it's very difficult to put out.
   "They will be very difficult to contain," said Mr Cheney, the former head of the CSIRO's bushfire research unit.
   "It's likely to burn for months.
   "It will be in the tens of millions of hectares."
   Heavy rain through Australia's centre has sparked prolific grass growth. It's now curing, or drying out, after recent drier weather.
   The thick band of grass extends from the Indian Ocean in the west to the Pacific Ocean in southern Queensland and the Great Dividing Range in NSW.
   "Essentially we've got a fuel bed that stretches from Sydney to Carnarvon, it goes right across the nation," said Chris Arnol, assistant chief operations officer (country) at the Fire & Emergency Services Authority of Western Australia.
   The Bushfire Cooperative Research Centre warns of the potential for above-normal bushfire activity across the middle of Australia, with grass fires posing the biggest risk this season.
   "We need to be particularly vigilant this year because grass fires start very easily, particularly once the grass is what's termed cured," Bushfire CRC deputy CEO and research director Richard Thornton said.
   "They can start very easily, they travel very rapidly and are very difficult to warn about," Dr Thornton said.
   Bushfire expert and former CSIRO principal research scientist David Packham believes huge grass fires are almost a certainty in the centre of Australia, if not this year then next year.
   "The centre, as everybody knows, has had heaps of rain, there's heaps of growth and they are going to have heaps of fires," Mr Packham said.
   "I would expect massive fires in the centre."
   Several fires have already broken out in central Australia, which doesn't have a fire season every year.
   "Central Australia is a slightly unusual event, this is probably a one-in-30-year event in central Australia," Bushfires Northern Territory director Steve Sutton said.
   "Central Australia is likely to continue with fires right through until the autumn, and we will have fires for most of that time," Mr Sutton said.
   Central Australia's variable winds can fan fire fronts spread over as much as 70 kilometres, he said.
   Grass fires can develop into quite significant fires in a matter of minutes, ACT Rural Fire Service chief officer Andrew Stark warned.
   Days of low humidity and strong winds bring an increased risk of bad grass fires, bringing trees down on power lines.
   "So many times right across Australia whenever you see one grass fire occurring in an area often you get a number of grass fires, and that'll be the challenge," Mr Stark said.
   Experts say the general trend is that if there's a serious grass season, it's usually a mild forest fire season.
   But as Victoria knows only too well after the Black Saturday bushfires, the bush can be just as volatile.
   "With the right weather conditions coming together - dry, hot, windy conditions - you're going to get a bushfire risk, you're going to get a grass fire risk under those conditions," NSW Rural Fire Brigade Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons said.
   In Western Australia, 80 per cent of the state faces the potential for above-average bushfire activity, much of it in grassland and pastoral areas in more isolated locations.
   But Mr Arnol said a key issue remained the forested "urban interface" area in the south-west corner despite the forecast of normal bushfire activity there.
   "A normal activity in our lower south-west still means that we will be facing the potential for significant fires - coastal, heathland and forest," he said.
   While the soil is moist in forested areas, it will only take a run of very hot days to quickly dry out the forests.
   "There's still a big risk," Dr Thornton said.
   "You should never be complacent of fire, particularly in Victoria or in NSW or any of those really hot places because forest fires are always a possibility.
   "But this year particularly, grass fires will be a bigger issue than they have been in the past."
   Dr Thornton says the Bushfire CRC's reports are not a prediction that there will be fires but that there is a greater likelihood of fires.
   There are no crystal balls to say how the season will actually pan out, South Australian Country Fire Service manager operations services Rob Sandford said.
   And no-one can control the weather.
   "If we get hot, really dry, windy weather, that will increase the risk because of the fuel loads right across the state and right across the nation," Mr Sandford said.
   Outback station owners, who've already been through tough times with the drought, will be in the frontline if there are major fires across the centre, Mr Packham said.
   But he said many were probably "on their knees" and not in a position to buy graders and to have sufficient people around to deal with the fires.
   "The fires are fast-moving. These people know how to deal with them, it's just that they haven't got the resources," Mr Packham said.
   "They need government assistance ... to have sufficient resources to be able to deal with them."
   Fire authorities have been talking about the risks this fire season, but the concern is that memories have faded since the last bad grass fire season, and for some reason the community thinks a grass fire isn't as bad as a bushfire.
   "A lot of people say it's only a grass fire. It can travel very very rapidly, it can change direction very rapidly and can catch people by surprise," Dr Thornton said.
   Mr Sandford said everyone needed a bushfire action plan even if they think they don't live in a bushfire-prone area, saying people who live in the suburbs around Australia will at some stage drive through a fire zone.
   "People that live there need one, but everyone needs one to ensure their best chances of survival," he said.
   "History shows that bushfires are a huge threat in the community and tragically people do die when these events occur."

urn:contentItem:6F7D-FNM3-RSSD-R3PS-00000-00No Headline1995-04-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:20ZLexisNexisPg. 34No Headline

KEYWORD-HIT Man on kill charge A SUNSHINE Coast man will appear in Maroochydore Magistrate's Court tomorrow facing a charge of murdering his 21-month-old son in September 1993. Victor Korin, 22, was questioned by Sunshine Coast Juvenile Aid Bureau chief detective Sen Sgt Chris Lill near Bega in New South Wales on Thursday and extradited on Friday. The toddler, Paul Robert Homer, died in a Brisbane hospital's intensive care unit. Crash injures two THE driver and a passenger of a car were treated in Royal Brisbane Hospital yesterday for injuries received when their vehicle ran out of control and crashed into a house on Kedron Brook Road, Wilston, about 12.45am. The injuries and damage to the property were not thought to be serious. Cyclone alert THE remote West Australian town of Derby has been warned to brace itself for winds of 110km/h or higher after tropical cyclone Chloe crossed the coast in the far north-east of Western Australia yesterday. The Weather Bureau said Chloe was moving inland in a general southerly direction and, and on its present course, would pass about 80km north-east of Derby. Wind gusts could reach 190km/h at the cyclone's centre, but the area the cyclone is passing through is reported to be uninhabited. Population rise THE Tweed Shire covering the New South Wales/Queensland border has increased its population by about 2000 _ making it one of the fastest-growing regions in NSW. The population grew from 55,440 to 57,190 from June 1992 to June 1993, according to recent figures from the Statistics Bureau. Curfew debate A BRISBANE University lecturer has entered the vexed Sunshine Coast nightclub curfew debate claiming earlier closure would not solve booze related problems such as street crime and vandalism. Mooloolaba and Noosa, two of the coast's biggest nightclub players, close their doors at 3am and the squeeze is on from locals for a midnight shutdown. Blitz on thefts SUNSHINE Coast police have launched a blitz on thefts from cars after statistics showed 261 were broken into on the coast last month, including well organised hit-and-run raids by motorbike riders lying in wait for tourists at National Parks and in beach car parks. Police appealed to visitors not to leave valuables in their vehicles. 29 children die A FOREST fire whipped by fierce winds has killed 29 primary-school children on an excursion in northern China, local officials said yesterday. The children died on April 6 when the fire erupted on a mountain in Huairen county in northern Shanxi province, an official said. Test lab to open A HEAVY structures testing laboratory capable of testing full-size bridge girders, will be opened at Griffith University's Gold Coast campus. The opening comes after increased demand for university staff who have previously tested heavy construction objects for the Gold Coast City Council. Fashion awards UP and coming creative talent will be celebrated this week when the 1995 Gold Coast Fashion Designer Awards are handed out. The awards, held at Conrad Jupiters Casino, are organised by the Gold Coast Welfare Committee, with all proceeds going to charity.
